Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Thematic study and historic environment
Topics.Topic_name: Crime and punishment in Britain, c1000–present

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval crime categories (person, property, authority) and ‘social’ crime
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the main categories of crime in medieval England: crimes against the person, property and authority; include poaching as a key example of ‘social’ crime (offences shaped by local economic pressures and popular attitudes).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Norman Conquest and changing definitions of crime (Forest Laws)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the Norman Conquest changed definitions of criminal activity; know William I’s Forest Laws and how they extended/reshaped what counted as crime against authority and property, and who was targeted.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Community and authority law enforcement (tithings; hue and cry; parish constable)
Sub_topics.description: Describe and explain medieval law enforcement as a local/community responsibility supported by authority: tithings (frankpledge), the hue and cry, and the parish constable; understand how these worked in practice to detect, pursue and present offenders.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval punishments: deterrence, retribution and fines
Sub_topics.description: Know the emphasis on deterrence and retribution in medieval punishment; describe the use of fines as a common penalty.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval corporal and capital punishment
Sub_topics.description: Describe the use of corporal punishment and capital punishment in the medieval period.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: End of wergild
Sub_topics.description: Understand the Saxon wergild system and why and when it ended.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Church influence: Sanctuary and Benefit of Clergy
Sub_topics.description: Explain the influence of the Church on crime and punishment in the early thirteenth century; know what Sanctuary and Benefit of Clergy were, how they affected trials/punishments, and why they were historically significant.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trial by ordeal and why it ended
Sub_topics.description: Describe trial by ordeal as a medieval method of determining guilt; explain reasons for its ending (including changing Church attitudes and official decisions) and the consequences for the legal process.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern crime: continuity and change; heresy and treason
Sub_topics.description: Know continuities and changes in crimes against the person, property and authority in early modern England; include heresy and treason as key examples linked to religious and political change and state authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: New crimes in the 16th century: vagabondage
Sub_topics.description: Explain why vagabondage became newly defined and targeted as a crime in the sixteenth century; link to social/economic change and government attitudes to poverty and order.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: New crimes in the 16th century: witchcraft
Sub_topics.description: Explain why witchcraft became newly defined and prosecuted as a crime in the sixteenth century; understand beliefs/attitudes that supported prosecutions and how authorities responded.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern law enforcement: authorities/local communities; town watchmen
Sub_topics.description: Describe the role of authorities and local communities in early modern law enforcement; know the functions and limitations of town watchmen and local policing arrangements.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern punishments: corporal/capital; transportation; beginnings of the Bloody Code
Sub_topics.description: Know continued use of corporal and capital punishment; explain introduction of transportation and how/why the Bloody Code began to develop (expansion of capital offences and deterrent intent).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Gunpowder Plot (1605) crimes and punishment
Sub_topics.description: Know what the Gunpowder Plotters did (their crimes as treason/attempted regicide) and how they were punished; explain why the punishment was severe and what it shows about authority and deterrence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Key individual: Matthew Hopkins and witch-hunts (1645–47)
Sub_topics.description: Explain who Matthew Hopkins was and his role in the witch-hunts of 1645–47; analyse reasons for their intensity and the typical punishments given to those convicted; link to war, fear, beliefs and local authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 18th–19th century crimes: continuity and change (highway robbery, poaching, smuggling)
Sub_topics.description: Describe and explain continuity and change in crimes against the person, property and authority in eighteenth- and nineteenth-century Britain; include highway robbery, poaching and smuggling as key examples and relate patterns to social and economic conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing definitions: end of witchcraft prosecutions
Sub_topics.description: Explain how and why witchcraft prosecutions ended; understand changing attitudes and legal developments that reduced belief-based prosecutions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing definitions: Tolpuddle Martyrs
Sub_topics.description: Know the Tolpuddle Martyrs case and how it illustrates changing definitions/treatment of ‘crime’ connected to protest, labour organisation and authority; explain why their actions were treated as criminal and what this shows about law and society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Law enforcement: Fielding brothers
Sub_topics.description: Describe the work of the Fielding brothers in eighteenth-century law enforcement (e.g., Bow Street Runners) and explain their significance in developing more organised policing and detection.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Development of police forces and beginnings of CID
Sub_topics.description: Explain why and how police forces developed in the nineteenth century; know key features of early professional policing and the beginnings of the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) and what changed in investigative methods.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing aims of punishment: transportation and its ending
Sub_topics.description: Explain changing views on the purpose of punishment; know the use of transportation, why it was used, and why/when it ended; link to prison development and public attitudes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing aims of punishment: public execution and its ending
Sub_topics.description: Describe the use of public execution as deterrence; explain reasons for the ending of public execution and the broader shift towards different penal aims (reform, surveillance, control).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing aims of punishment: Bloody Code and its ending
Sub_topics.description: Explain the Bloody Code in eighteenth-century Britain, why it expanded, and why/when it ended; link to changing attitudes, reformers and practicality of enforcement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prison reform: John Howard
Sub_topics.description: Explain John Howard’s role and ideas in prison reform; know problems he identified (conditions, health, discipline) and how his work influenced changes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prison reform: Elizabeth Fry
Sub_topics.description: Explain Elizabeth Fry’s role and ideas in prison reform; know her focus (e.g., treatment of prisoners, especially women, moral reform) and the impact of her work.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Pentonville Prison and the separate system
Sub_topics.description: Know why Pentonville Prison was built in the mid-nineteenth century; describe the separate system in operation; evaluate strengths and weaknesses (deterrence/reform aims, psychological effects, discipline).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Key individual: Robert Peel (police and penal reform)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Robert Peel’s contribution to penal reform and to establishing the Metropolitan Police Force; know key principles associated with ‘Peelian’ policing and why they mattered.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern crimes: continuity and change; new forms of theft and smuggling
Sub_topics.description: Describe continuity and change in modern crimes against the person, property and authority; include new forms of theft and smuggling and relate to technological/social changes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing definitions: driving offences
Sub_topics.description: Explain how and why driving offences became defined as crimes; link to mass car use, regulation, public safety and enforcement methods.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing definitions: race crimes
Sub_topics.description: Explain how and why race crimes became defined and prosecuted; link to migration, social attitudes, legislation and changing expectations of equality and protection.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing definitions: drug crimes
Sub_topics.description: Explain how and why drug crimes expanded/changed in the modern period; link to changing laws, public health concerns, organised crime and policing priorities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern law enforcement: Neighbourhood Watch and community role
Sub_topics.description: Explain the role of local communities and authorities in modern law enforcement; know what Neighbourhood Watch is and how it reflects prevention, community cooperation and changing policing strategies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern policing: specialisation (within police forces)
Sub_topics.description: Describe changes within the police force towards increasing specialisation (specialist units/roles); explain why specialisation developed and how it changed effectiveness and priorities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern policing: science and technology in law enforcement
Sub_topics.description: Explain how science and technology have been used in modern policing and investigation; understand the significance of forensic and technological developments for detection, evidence and prevention.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern policing: move towards prevention
Sub_topics.description: Explain the shift in policing aims towards prevention (rather than only reaction/punishment); link to policy, public expectations, community initiatives and new technology.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Abolition of the death penalty
Sub_topics.description: Know the process and significance of abolishing the death penalty in Britain; explain reasons for abolition and how attitudes, key cases, and institutions influenced change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prison changes: open prisons
Sub_topics.description: Describe the development and purpose of open prisons; explain how they reflect changing aims of punishment (rehabilitation, resettlement) and evaluate perceived strengths/criticisms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Youth justice: specialised treatment of young offenders
Sub_topics.description: Explain how and why the treatment of young offenders became specialised; link to changing attitudes to youth, rehabilitation, and distinct institutions/programmes for young people.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Non-custodial alternatives to prison
Sub_topics.description: Describe the development of non-custodial alternatives (e.g., probation, community sentences) and explain why they expanded; link to rehabilitation, cost, overcrowding and effectiveness debates.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Conscientious Objectors in WWI and WWII
Sub_topics.description: Know how Conscientious Objectors were treated in the First and Second World Wars; explain why they were seen as criminal/against authority, the range of punishments or exemptions, and what this shows about attitudes and the state.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Derek Bentley and the death penalty
Sub_topics.description: Know key facts of the Derek Bentley case and explain its significance in debates leading to the abolition of the death penalty; link to issues of justice, responsibility, and public opinion.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Thematic study and historic environment
Topics.Topic_name: Whitechapel, c1870–c1900: crime, policing and the inner city

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Whitechapel conditions: housing, overcrowding and Peabody Estate reforms
Sub_topics.description: Explain the local context of Whitechapel c1870–c1900 focusing on housing problems and overcrowding; know attempts to improve housing including the Peabody Estate and what it aimed to change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Workhouses and provision for the poor in Whitechapel
Sub_topics.description: Describe provision for the poor through Whitechapel workhouses; explain how workhouses functioned and how poverty relief related to local living conditions and crime.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Links between inner-city environment and crime
Sub_topics.description: Analyse links between the Whitechapel environment (poverty, overcrowding, discontent) and patterns of crime; explain why inner-city conditions could encourage crime and hinder policing.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Employment, poverty and a fluctuating population
Sub_topics.description: Explain who lived in Whitechapel and why: lack of employment opportunities, high poverty; prevalence of lodging houses and pubs creating a fluctuating population with weak community ties; link to crime levels and policing difficulties.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migration in Whitechapel: Irish and Eastern European/Jewish settlement
Sub_topics.description: Explain changing patterns of migration into Whitechapel: settlement of Irish and Eastern European migrants and the increase in Jewish migration during the 1880s; analyse effects on community relations, work, housing and policing.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Beat policing and H Division challenges in slum areas
Sub_topics.description: Describe the organisation of policing in Whitechapel, including the role of the beat constable and the work of H Division; explain difficulties policing rookeries, alleys and courts and how the physical layout hindered surveillance and response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Policing problems: alcohol, prostitution, rackets, gangs and demonstrations
Sub_topics.description: Know key crimes/antisocial behaviours that complicated policing: alcohol-related disorder, prostitution, protection rackets, gangs, violent demonstrations; explain why these were prevalent and hard to control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Attacks on Jewish people and community tensions
Sub_topics.description: Explain problems of policing caused by attacks on Jewish people; understand sources of tension, public order issues and the impact on policing and community relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Detective investigation methods: sketches, photographs and interviews
Sub_topics.description: Describe developments in investigative policing in Whitechapel including the use of sketches, photographs and interviews; explain how these methods supported detection and their limitations in this period.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Jurisdiction and cooperation issues: Met Police, City of London Police, Scotland Yard
Sub_topics.description: Explain problems caused by the need for cooperation between the Metropolitan Police, the City of London Police and Scotland Yard; understand how jurisdictional boundaries and coordination affected investigations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Jack the Ripper murders: policing challenges and media influence
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the Jack the Ripper murders tested policing; analyse added problems caused by media reporting and public pressure; know the role and significance of the Whitechapel Vigilance Committee.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metropolitan Police, recruits, CID, Home Secretary, Charles Warren and public attitudes
Sub_topics.description: Explain national/regional context: how the Metropolitan Police worked, the quality of police recruits, development of CID; roles of the Home Secretary and Sir Charles Warren; analyse public attitudes towards the police and how they shaped policing.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Local sources for enquiries: housing/employment, council/census, Booth, workhouse, police, coroners, photos, newspapers
Sub_topics.description: Know local sources relevant to Whitechapel enquiries (e.g., housing and employment records, council records and census returns, Charles Booth’s survey, workhouse records, local police records, coroners’ reports, photographs, London newspapers); understand what each source type can reveal about crime, poverty, policing and living conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: National sources for enquiries: national newspapers, investigation records, Old Bailey trials, Punch cartoons
Sub_topics.description: Know national sources relevant to Whitechapel enquiries (e.g., national newspapers, records of crimes and police investigations, Old Bailey trial records, Punch cartoons); understand the kinds of evidence and viewpoints each provides.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Strengths and weaknesses of different source types for specific enquiries
Sub_topics.description: Apply source evaluation to Whitechapel: recognise strengths and weaknesses of different types of source (official records, journalism, cartoons, photographs, personal accounts) for answering specific historical enquiries about crime, policing, and social conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Framing enquiry questions about Whitechapel
Sub_topics.description: Be able to frame historically valid questions for a specific enquiry into Whitechapel c1870–c1900 (e.g., about causes of crime, effectiveness of policing, impact of migration), ensuring questions are focused and evidence-led.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Selecting appropriate sources for an investigation
Sub_topics.description: Select appropriate sources (local and/or national) to investigate a specified Whitechapel enquiry; justify selection by relevance, provenance, and what the sources can/cannot show.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Thematic study and historic environment

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Supernatural and religious causes of disease (medieval)
Sub_topics.description: Know and explain supernatural and religious explanations for disease in medieval England (e.g., God’s punishment, sin, astrology) and how these shaped responses to illness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Four Humours and miasma; Galen’s influence
Sub_topics.description: Explain rational explanations for disease in medieval England: Theory of the Four Humours and miasma theory; understand and describe Galen’s continuing influence on English medical thinking and practice.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval prevention and treatment methods linked to beliefs
Sub_topics.description: Describe approaches to prevention and treatment in medieval England and connect them to beliefs about disease: religious actions (prayer, pilgrimage), bloodletting and purging, and attempts to purify the air.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medical training and roles: physician, apothecary, barber surgeon; care settings and herbal remedies
Sub_topics.description: Know medical training/traditional care in medieval England: roles of physician, apothecary and barber surgeon; role of hospitals; care within the community and at home; use of herbal remedies and practical treatments.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Black Death (1348–49) responses
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the Black Death was dealt with in 1348–49: approaches to treatment and attempts to prevent spread; link responses to contemporary medical ideas and religious beliefs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medical Renaissance: continuity/change in causes; Sydenham and diagnosis
Sub_topics.description: Explain continuity and change in explanations of disease in the Medical Renaissance; understand the growth of scientific approaches including Thomas Sydenham’s work improving diagnosis and observation-based medicine.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Printing press and Royal Society: transmission of medical ideas
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the printing press and the Royal Society influenced the transmission of medical ideas and contributed to changes in understanding and practice in England.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Continuity/change in prevention, treatment and care (community/hospitals)
Sub_topics.description: Describe continuity and change in approaches to prevention, treatment and care during 1500–1700 in both community and hospitals; link to persistence of traditional remedies and emerging experimentation/observation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medical training improvements; Vesalius’ influence in England
Sub_topics.description: Explain improvements in medical training and anatomy; understand the influence in England of Vesalius’ anatomical work and why it challenged earlier authority-based medicine.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Key individual: William Harvey and blood circulation
Sub_topics.description: Know Harvey’s discovery of the circulation of the blood; explain how he developed/argued his ideas and why this was significant for medical knowledge and later developments.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Great Plague (London, 1665)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how London dealt with the Great Plague in 1665: treatments and public measures to prevent spread (quarantine, plague orders); link to miasma/four humours and government/church roles.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Germ Theory and Koch: changing explanations of disease
Sub_topics.description: Explain continuity and change in disease explanations in 1700–1900; understand Pasteur’s Germ Theory and Koch’s work on microbes and how these shifted medical understanding in Britain.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hospital care and Nightingale’s influence on nursing/hospitals
Sub_topics.description: Explain the extent of change in care and treatment: improvements in hospital care and Florence Nightingale’s influence on nursing standards and hospital organisation in Britain.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anaesthetics and antiseptics: impact on surgery
Sub_topics.description: Explain the impact of anaesthetics and antiseptics on surgery in Britain; understand how they changed pain management, infection rates, and what operations were possible.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Vaccination development and use; Public Health Act (1875)
Sub_topics.description: Describe new prevention approaches: development and use of vaccinations; know the Public Health Act (1875) and how it improved sanitation and public health, reducing disease.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Key individual: Edward Jenner and vaccination
Sub_topics.description: Know Jenner’s development of vaccination (smallpox) and explain why it was significant; link to scientific method, public acceptance, and later immunisation programmes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Cholera in London (1854) and John Snow
Sub_topics.description: Explain attempts to prevent cholera’s spread in London (1854); analyse the significance of John Snow and the Broad Street pump for challenging miasma theory and advancing public health practice.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern understanding of health: genetic and lifestyle factors
Sub_topics.description: Explain advances in understanding causes of illness/disease in the modern period, including the influence of genetic factors and lifestyle factors (diet, smoking, exercise) on health.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern diagnosis: blood tests, scans and monitors
Sub_topics.description: Explain improvements in diagnosis due to the availability and use of blood tests, medical scans (e.g., X-ray/CT/MRI conceptually) and patient monitoring; link to earlier scientific/technological progress.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: NHS: improved access to care
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the NHS changed medical care in Britain by improving access; link to government role, equity, and changes in public expectations of healthcare.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern medicines: magic bullets and antibiotics
Sub_topics.description: Explain advances in medicines including ‘magic bullets’ and antibiotics; understand what these are, why they were breakthroughs, and their impact on treating infection and disease.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: High-tech treatment and surgery in hospitals
Sub_topics.description: Explain the growth of high-tech medical and surgical treatment in hospitals (specialised equipment, advanced procedures); link to science and technology as drivers of change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prevention: mass vaccinations and lifestyle campaigns
Sub_topics.description: Describe modern prevention approaches: mass vaccination programmes and government lifestyle campaigns; explain aims, methods (public information, screening encouragement) and impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Key individuals: Fleming, Florey and Chain and penicillin
Sub_topics.description: Know the roles of Fleming, Florey and Chain in the development of penicillin; explain why development required multiple contributions (discovery, purification/testing, mass production) and its impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: lung cancer in the 21st century
Sub_topics.description: Explain the fight against lung cancer in the twenty-first century: use of science and technology in diagnosis and treatment; government action (public health policy, anti-smoking measures, awareness).

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Thematic study and historic environment
Topics.Topic_name: The British sector of the Western Front, 1914–18: injuries, treatment and the trenches

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: British sector context: Flanders/N France (Ypres, Somme, Arras, Cambrai) and trench system
Sub_topics.description: Know the context of the British sector of the Western Front in Flanders and northern France including Ypres salient, the Somme, Arras and Cambrai; describe trench system organisation (frontline and support trenches) and why this context mattered for medical care.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Terrain and infrastructure: impact on treatment, transport and communications
Sub_topics.description: Explain the significance of terrain and problems of transport/communications infrastructure for medical treatment and evacuation on the Western Front; link to mud, shelling, distance and logistical limits.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ill health from trench conditions
Sub_topics.description: Describe conditions requiring medical treatment arising from trench life (ill health due to environment) and explain why these were common and challenging to treat/prevent.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nature of wounds: rifles/explosives, shrapnel, infection and head injuries
Sub_topics.description: Explain the nature of wounds from rifles and explosives; understand shrapnel injuries, wound infection, and increased numbers of head injuries, and why these changed medical needs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Effects of gas attacks
Sub_topics.description: Describe the effects of gas attacks on soldiers’ health and medical treatment demands; understand why gas created new treatment challenges.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: RAMC and nurses on the Western Front
Sub_topics.description: Explain roles of the Royal Army Medical Corps (RAMC) and nurses in treating casualties; understand organisation of care and constraints under fire.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chain of evacuation transport: stretcher bearers, horse and motor ambulances
Sub_topics.description: Describe how casualties were moved: stretcher bearers, horse ambulances and motor ambulances; explain how transport affected survival and speed of treatment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stages of treatment: aid post → field ambulance → dressing station → CCS → base hospital; Arras underground hospital
Sub_topics.description: Know stages of the chain of evacuation and treatment: aid post/field ambulance, dressing station, casualty clearing station (CCS), base hospital; include the underground hospital at Arras and why it was significant.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Western Front innovations: wound treatment, Thomas splint, mobile X-ray, blood bank (Cambrai)
Sub_topics.description: Explain why the Western Front was significant for experiments in surgery/medicine; know new techniques for treating wounds/infection, the Thomas splint, mobile X-ray units, and creation of a blood bank for the Battle of Cambrai; link to improved survival.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pre-war medical context: infection/aseptic surgery, X-rays, transfusions and blood storage
Sub_topics.description: Know the historical context of early twentieth-century medicine relevant to wartime treatment: understanding of infection and moves towards aseptic surgery; development of X-rays; blood transfusions and developments in blood storage.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: National sources for Western Front enquiries
Sub_topics.description: Know national sources relevant to enquiries on Western Front medicine (e.g., army records, national newspapers, government reports, medical articles) and what evidence each can provide.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Local sources for Western Front enquiries
Sub_topics.description: Know local sources relevant to enquiries (e.g., personal accounts, photographs, hospital records, army statistics) and what each can reveal about injuries, treatment and experience.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evaluating strengths/weaknesses of source types
Sub_topics.description: Recognise and explain strengths and weaknesses of different source types (official records, medical publications, personal testimony, images, statistics) for answering specific Western Front medical enquiries.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Framing enquiry questions about Western Front treatment
Sub_topics.description: Frame focused questions for historical enquiries into injuries, evacuation and treatment on the Western Front, ensuring questions can be answered with available evidence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Selecting appropriate sources for an investigation
Sub_topics.description: Select and justify appropriate sources for investigating a specific issue about Western Front injuries/treatment/trenches, matching evidence type to enquiry needs.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Thematic study and historic environment

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval army composition and social structure
Sub_topics.description: Describe composition of medieval armies (infantry, archer, mounted knight) and explain the link between social structure (feudal hierarchy) and army command/leadership.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: New weapons/formations: longbow and schiltrons
Sub_topics.description: Explain how new weapons and formations affected medieval warfare strategy, tactics and combat; include longbow and schiltrons as key examples and their battlefield impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gunpowder and cannon; decline of mounted knight
Sub_topics.description: Explain importance of gunpowder and development of cannon; analyse how these changes contributed to the decline of the mounted knight’s dominance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Recruitment and training in the feudal army
Sub_topics.description: Describe recruitment and training of medieval combatants within the feudal system; understand obligations and the practicalities of raising forces.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of war on civilians: feudal duties and plunder
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of medieval warfare on civilians, including burdens of feudal duties and the effects of plunder on lives and livelihoods.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Battle of Falkirk (1298) outcome and roles (Wallace, Edward I)
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for the outcome of the Battle of Falkirk (1298); explain roles of William Wallace and Edward I and how tactics/leadership affected results.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Battle of Agincourt (1415) outcome and role of Henry V
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for the outcome of the Battle of Agincourt (1415); explain role of Henry V and how weapons/tactics/conditions influenced victory.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern army composition: musketeers, pikemen, dragoons, cavalry; standing army
Sub_topics.description: Explain continuity and change in sixteenth–seventeenth century army composition (musketeer, pikemen, dragoons, cavalry) and the development of a standing army; link to state capacity and warfare needs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weaponry developments: muskets and pistols
Sub_topics.description: Describe developments in weaponry (improved muskets and pistols) and explain their impact on tactics, training and battlefield effectiveness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Recruitment and training: New Model Army
Sub_topics.description: Describe recruitment and training in early modern warfare; explain the New Model Army’s features and why it represented change in organisation, discipline and professionalism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact on civilians: recruitment and requisitioning
Sub_topics.description: Explain the impact of early modern war on civilians, including recruitment demands and requisitioning of supplies; link to state power and economic disruption.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Battle of Naseby (1645) outcome and role of Cromwell
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for the outcome of the Battle of Naseby (1645); explain Oliver Cromwell’s role and how New Model Army organisation/tactics shaped the result.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 18th–19th century army composition: continuity/change; decline of cavalry
Sub_topics.description: Describe continuity and change in army composition in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries; explain the decline of cavalry and reasons for shifting battlefield roles.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weaponry changes: rifles/bullets, field guns and heavy artillery
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of weaponry changes (rifles and bullets, field guns, heavy artillery) on warfare, including increased range/lethality and tactical adaptations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Industrialisation’s impact: steam transport and mass weapon production
Sub_topics.description: Explain how industrialisation affected warfare, including steam-powered transport and mass production of weapons; link to logistics, mobilisation and scale of conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Recruitment/training and professionalisation: Cardwell’s reforms
Sub_topics.description: Describe recruitment and training changes including Cardwell’s army reforms; explain how reforms professionalised the army and altered service conditions/reserves.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Civilians and media: newspapers/photography (Crimean and Boer Wars)
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of war on civilians through recruitment and requisitioning; analyse how growth of newspaper reporting and photography influenced popular attitudes to war, exemplified by Crimean and Boer Wars.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Battle of Waterloo (1815) outcome and role of Wellington
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for the outcome of Waterloo (1815); explain the Duke of Wellington’s role and factors such as tactics, coalition forces, and timing.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Battle of Balaclava (1854) outcome and role of Lord Raglan
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for the outcome of Balaclava (1854); explain Lord Raglan’s role and how command, communication and tactics affected events.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern army composition: logistics corps and bomb disposal units
Sub_topics.description: Describe continuity and change in modern army composition including growth of logistics corps and specialised bomb disposal units; explain why specialisation increased.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern weaponry and tech: machine guns, tanks, chemical and nuclear weapons
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact on warfare of developments in weaponry and technology including machine guns, tanks, chemical weapons and nuclear weapons; relate to changes in tactics, casualties and deterrence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radar and aircraft; surveillance and high-tech warfare
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of radar and aircraft on warfare, including surveillance and aerial support; analyse the rise of computerised/high-tech warfare and how it changed planning and operations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Motor/air transport and aerial support
Sub_topics.description: Describe increasing use of motor and air transport and aerial support; explain consequences for mobility, supply, strategy and speed of campaigns.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Guerrilla warfare in the 21st century
Sub_topics.description: Explain challenges of dealing with guerrilla warfare in the twenty-first century and how it shapes tactics, technology use, and civilian impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conscription, national service, women’s recruitment and professional army
Sub_topics.description: Describe recruitment and training changes: introduction of conscription and national service; recruitment of women; development of a professional army; explain reasons and impacts for society and warfare capacity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Home Front organisation in WWI and WWII
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of war on civilians via organisation of the Home Front during the First and Second World Wars (mobilisation, civil defence, rationing conceptually) and how this changed civilian experience.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fear of nuclear war after 1945
Sub_topics.description: Explain post-1945 civilian fear of nuclear war and its consequences for society, government policy and attitudes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Attitudes to Conscientious Objectors
Sub_topics.description: Explain attitudes to Conscientious Objectors in modern Britain; link to patriotism, morality, law and government policy during wartime.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: War reporting, casualties and public attitudes
Sub_topics.description: Analyse influence of war reporting on attitudes in the modern period, including increased concern for casualties; link to media coverage, public opinion and political pressure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Censorship and propaganda in wartime
Sub_topics.description: Explain government use of censorship and propaganda in wartime; analyse aims, methods and effects on morale, support for war and information control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Somme (1916), trench warfare/attrition and Haig
Sub_topics.description: Know nature of trench warfare and war of attrition on the Western Front; explain reasons for the outcome of the Battle of the Somme (1916) and assess the role of General Haig.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Iraq War (2003) outcome and high-tech surveillance/weaponry
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for the outcome of the Iraq War (2003); analyse use of high-tech weaponry and surveillance techniques and how they shaped the conduct and consequences of the conflict.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Thematic study and historic environment
Topics.Topic_name: London and the Second World War, 1939–45

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why London was significant and a target in WWII
Sub_topics.description: Explain the context of London in WWII: role in national government, significance as a target, importance as a port and industrial centre, and accessibility for German bombers; link to strategic bombing aims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Preparations: evacuation, Anderson shelters and gas masks
Sub_topics.description: Describe preparations for war in London in 1939 and ongoing safeguarding measures: implementation of evacuation plans, provision and purpose of Anderson shelters, and distribution/use of gas masks.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Targets and key events: docks/East End, Black Saturday (7 Sept 1940), V2 Deptford (1944)
Sub_topics.description: Describe nature of attacks on London: focus on docks and industries of the East End; know Black Saturday (7 September 1940) and the V2 attack on Deptford (1944) as examples; explain their significance and impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bomb types in 1940–41 and 1944–45; devastation; incendiaries, V1 and V2
Sub_topics.description: Know types of bombs used in 1940–41 and 1944–45; explain scale and extent of devastation; understand problems dealing with incendiary bombs and the threat posed by V1 and V2 rockets.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Air-raid precautions: Underground stations and ‘Mickey’s shelter’
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of the Blitz on civilian life through air-raid precautions (ARP); describe use of Underground stations and ‘Mickey’s shelter’ and how sheltering shaped daily life and safety.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: South Hallsville School (1940) and Bethnal Green (1943) disasters
Sub_topics.description: Know the South Hallsville School disaster (1940) and Bethnal Green disaster (1943); explain causes and what they reveal about risks of bombing/sheltering and government response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Leisure continuity and morale: dancehalls and theatre; disruption to work/daily life
Sub_topics.description: Explain continuance of leisure activities (dancehalls, theatre) during the Blitz; assess extent of disruption to daily life/work and explain government concerns about morale.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: London’s response: Royal Family, ministers and Cabinet War Rooms
Sub_topics.description: Describe London’s response to war: continued presence of the Royal Family and government ministers; know the Cabinet War Rooms and their significance for leadership and morale.

Sub_topics.Specification_section_sub: London WWII 1 (Public space and Dig for Victory)
Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Using public spaces for ‘Dig for Victory’ (Victoria Park; Tower of London moat)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how public spaces (Victoria Park, Tower of London moat) were used for the ‘Dig for Victory’ campaign; analyse why this mattered for food supply, morale and community mobilisation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Purpose of the Blitz; propaganda and censorship
Sub_topics.description: Explain the nature and purpose of the Blitz within the wider WWII context; analyse government use of propaganda and censorship to influence attitudes about the Blitz and maintain morale.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Local sources for London Blitz enquiries
Sub_topics.description: Know local sources for enquiries into London 1939–45 (personal accounts, photographs, local newspapers, local council records) and what each can show about experience and impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: National sources: government records, newspapers, Mass Observation, newsreels, memoirs
Sub_topics.description: Know national sources (government records, newspapers, Mass Observation reports, newsreels, memoirs) relevant to London WWII enquiries and the perspectives/limitations they bring.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evaluating strengths/weaknesses of sources for Blitz enquiries
Sub_topics.description: Recognise strengths and weaknesses of different sources (official, media, personal) for specific enquiries about bombing, ARP, morale, and daily life in London.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Framing enquiry questions about London in WWII
Sub_topics.description: Frame focused historical enquiry questions about London 1939–45 (e.g., effectiveness of ARP, impact on morale, government leadership) suitable for investigation using evidence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Selecting sources for a specific Blitz investigation
Sub_topics.description: Select and justify appropriate sources for a specified investigation into London and the Blitz, matching source type to enquiry and recognising bias/provenance.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Thematic study and historic environment

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval migration: Vikings, Normans, Jews, European traders/craftsmen (reasons and settlement)
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for migration to medieval England and patterns of settlement; include Vikings, Normans, Jews and other European traders/craftsmen; focus on pull factors drawing migrants to Britain while recognising push factors at a basic level.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval English context: landownership, towns, wool industry, royal finance, Christendom
Sub_topics.description: Explain context of English society that shaped opportunities for migrants: landownership, growth of towns, role of the wool industry, monarchy’s need for royal finance, and England as part of Christendom; link context to migration patterns.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migrant experience: relations with authorities/population; ‘alien’ status; Black Death impact
Sub_topics.description: Explain migrants’ experiences: relations with authorities and existing population; understand legal status of ‘alien’ and how it affected rights; explain impact of the Black Death on migrants and attitudes/policies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migrant impact: Danelaw, culture, trade and built environment
Sub_topics.description: Explain impacts of migrants in medieval England including the Danelaw and wider cultural, trade and built-environment influences; give examples of lasting change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Viking York
Sub_topics.description: Know key features of the city of York under the Vikings; explain how migration shaped settlement, economy, culture and governance in this case study.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern migration: Europe and Africa (reasons and settlement)
Sub_topics.description: Explain continuity and change in reasons for migration and settlement patterns in early modern England, including migrants from Europe and Africa; focus on pull factors such as work, trade and security.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern context: social change, cloth industry, global trading companies, privateering, Protestant England
Sub_topics.description: Explain changing English context: changing social structures, economic growth (cloth industry), global trading companies, privateering and trade, and emergence of a predominantly Protestant nation; link these to migration.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern migrant experience: relations with authorities/population
Sub_topics.description: Describe experiences of migrants in early modern England and relations with authorities and existing population; consider acceptance, regulation, suspicion and local responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern migrant impact: culture, trade, industry and agriculture
Sub_topics.description: Explain impacts of migrants in early modern England on culture, trade, industry and agriculture; link specific skills/industries to migrant groups.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Flemish/Walloon migrants in Sandwich and Canterbury
Sub_topics.description: Know experiences of Flemish and Walloon migrants in Sandwich and Canterbury in the sixteenth century; explain their economic roles and local impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Huguenots in 17th-century England
Sub_topics.description: Explain why Huguenots migrated and describe their experiences in seventeenth-century England; analyse economic/cultural contributions and reactions from authorities and locals.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 18th–19th century migration: Ireland, Europe and Empire (reasons and settlement)
Sub_topics.description: Explain change and continuity in reasons for migration and settlement patterns including migrants from Ireland, Europe and the Empire; relate to industrial opportunities, urban growth and imperial connections.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 18th–19th century context: Industrial Revolution, urbanisation, slavery, Empire, civil liberties
Sub_topics.description: Explain changing British context: social structure change, Industrial Revolution, urbanisation, transatlantic slavery, growth of British Empire and civil liberties; link these to migration flows and settlement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migrant experience and the role of the media (18th–19th)
Sub_topics.description: Explain experiences of migrants and their relations with authorities and existing population in eighteenth/nineteenth-century Britain; analyse the role of the media in shaping attitudes and responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migrant impact (18th–19th): culture, trade/industry, politics and urban environment
Sub_topics.description: Explain impacts of migrants on British culture, trade and industry, politics and the urban environment in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries; use examples to show change/continuity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Liverpool as a migration hub; Irish migrant experiences
Sub_topics.description: Know Liverpool’s role in nineteenth-century migration and describe migrant experiences there, including Irish migrants; link to port economy, housing and community relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Jewish migrants in the East End (late 19th century)
Sub_topics.description: Explain experiences of Jewish migrants in the East End of London in the late nineteenth century; consider work, housing, prejudice and community support networks.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern migration: Ireland, Europe, Empire/Commonwealth; refugees and asylum seekers
Sub_topics.description: Explain change and continuity in reasons for migration and settlement patterns in modern Britain, including migrants from Ireland, Europe, the British Empire and the Commonwealth; include refugees and asylum seekers; focus on pull factors such as labour demand and safety.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern context: World Wars, decolonisation/Commonwealth, EU membership
Sub_topics.description: Explain changing context of British society in the twentieth century: the World Wars, end of Empire, decolonisation and development of the Commonwealth, and EU membership; link these to migration patterns and policy debates.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Immigration/nationality legislation: Aliens Act (1905) and British Nationality Acts
Sub_topics.description: Know key legislation shaping migration and nationality, including the Aliens Act (1905) and British Nationality Acts; explain aims, how they changed rights/controls, and consequences for migrants.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern migrant experience: anti-immigration and equal rights movements; Race Relations Act (1965)
Sub_topics.description: Explain experiences of migrants in modern Britain and relations with authorities and existing population; include anti-immigration movements and equal rights movements; know the Race Relations Act (1965) and its significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Media and migration (modern Britain)
Sub_topics.description: Analyse the role of the media in shaping attitudes towards migrants in modern Britain; consider how portrayal influenced public opinion and policy responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern migrant impact: culture, politics, urban environment, public services and economy
Sub_topics.description: Explain impacts of migrants on Britain in the modern period including culture, politics, the urban environment, public services and the economy; link to continuity and change over time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Bristol mid-20th century migrants and impact
Sub_topics.description: Know experiences of migrants in mid-twentieth-century Bristol and explain their impact on society; consider work, housing, community relations and cultural change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Case study: Asian migrants in Leicester (from 1945)
Sub_topics.description: Explain experiences of Asian migrants in Leicester from 1945; analyse settlement, employment, discrimination/support and long-term impact on the city and wider society.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Thematic study and historic environment

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why Caribbean migrants moved to Notting Hill
Sub_topics.description: Explain local context of Notting Hill and reasons for Caribbean migration to the area after 1948; link to post-war labour demand, housing availability and community networks.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Housing: HMOs, overcrowding, slum landlords and Peter Rachman
Sub_topics.description: Describe housing problems in Notting Hill: houses of multiple occupation (HMOs), overcrowding and slum landlords; know Peter Rachman as an example and explain how housing exploitation affected migrants and tensions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bruce Kenrick and the Notting Hill Housing Trust
Sub_topics.description: Know Bruce Kenrick and the Notting Hill Housing Trust; explain aims, actions and significance in improving housing and combating exploitation/poor conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Development of Portobello Road market
Sub_topics.description: Explain development of Portobello Road market and its significance to the area’s economy, community life and cultural change in Notting Hill c1948–c1970.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Caribbean cultural influence: shops, cafes, restaurants, shebeens, nightclubs, entertainment
Sub_topics.description: Explain influence of Caribbean cultures on Notting Hill through development of shops, markets, cafes/restaurants, shebeens, nightclubs and entertainment featuring Caribbean food and music; link to identity and community cohesion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: All Saints Road and Caribbean cultural life
Sub_topics.description: Know development of All Saints Road and explain its significance as a centre of Caribbean cultural and social life in Notting Hill.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mutual self-help: ‘pardner’ schemes
Sub_topics.description: Explain mutual self-help organisations including ‘pardner’ schemes; describe how they worked and why they were important for migrants facing discrimination and limited access to finance/support.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Notting Hill Riots (1958) and policing
Sub_topics.description: Know causes, events and significance of the Notting Hill Riots (1958); explain relationship between racism, policing and community relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Murder of Kelso Cochrane and community reaction
Sub_topics.description: Know the murder of Kelso Cochrane and explain reactions of the local community; analyse significance for anti-racism activism and public awareness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oswald Mosley’s Union Movement and 1959 campaign
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of anti-immigrant groups including Oswald Mosley’s Union Movement and his 1959 election campaign; link to local/national politics and racism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Claudia Jones and the West Indian Gazette
Sub_topics.description: Know Claudia Jones’ role in Black activism; explain the purpose and significance of the West Indian Gazette in supporting community voice, organisation and anti-racist politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1959 Caribbean Carnival and development of Notting Hill Carnival
Sub_topics.description: Explain the 1959 Caribbean Carnival and how it developed into the Notting Hill Carnival; analyse significance for cultural expression, community cohesion and public perceptions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Frank Crichlow, Mangrove Restaurant, British Black Panthers and the Mangrove Nine
Sub_topics.description: Know Frank Crichlow and the Mangrove Restaurant as centres of activism; explain the role of the British Black Panthers and the significance of the ‘Mangrove Nine’ case for policing, protest and Black rights.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Britain post-war: reconstruction, labour demand, Empire/Commonwealth links, Swinging Sixties, poverty, London policing
Sub_topics.description: Explain the national/regional context shaping Notting Hill: post-war reconstruction and labour demand; connections to the British Empire and Commonwealth; the ‘Swinging Sixties’; poverty in London; policing in London and its relationship with minority communities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Local sources for Notting Hill enquiries
Sub_topics.description: Know local sources relevant to Notting Hill c1948–c1970 (local newspapers, Caribbean community publications, local council and police records, housing/employment records, oral/written memoirs, photographs) and what each can show about migration, racism and culture.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: National sources for Notting Hill enquiries
Sub_topics.description: Know national sources (national newspapers, photographs, government records, census data, opinion polls, television reports, memoirs) relevant to Notting Hill enquiries; understand perspectives and limitations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Strengths and weaknesses of sources for Notting Hill
Sub_topics.description: Recognise strengths and weaknesses of different source types for specific enquiries into Notting Hill (e.g., bias in press, limitations of official records, value of oral testimony).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Framing enquiry questions about Notting Hill
Sub_topics.description: Frame focused historical enquiry questions about Notting Hill (housing, policing, activism, cultural change) appropriate to the evidence available.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Selecting sources for a Notting Hill investigation
Sub_topics.description: Select and justify appropriate sources to investigate a specified Notting Hill issue, matching evidence to enquiry and accounting for provenance and representativeness.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Period study and British depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-Saxon monarchy and government
Sub_topics.description: Know key features of Anglo-Saxon monarchy and government: power of the English monarchy; earldoms; local government and the legal system; how authority was exercised before 1066.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-Saxon economy, society and the Church
Sub_topics.description: Describe Anglo-Saxon economy and social system: towns and villages; understand the influence/role of the Church in society and governance before the Conquest.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: House of Godwin and Harold as Earl of Wessex
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance and power of the house of Godwin; know Harold Godwinson’s succession as Earl of Wessex and why this mattered for the succession crisis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Harold’s embassy to Normandy
Sub_topics.description: Know Harold Godwinson’s embassy to Normandy and explain its significance for William’s claim and later propaganda/justification.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tostig’s exile: causes of rising
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for the rising against Tostig and his exile; link to governance, regional power and instability before 1066.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Death of Edward the Confessor
Sub_topics.description: Know circumstances/significance of Edward the Confessor’s death and how it triggered the succession crisis of 1066.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rival claimants: William, Harald Hardrada, Edgar Aethling (motives and claims)
Sub_topics.description: Explain motives and claims of William of Normandy, Harald Hardrada and Edgar the Aethling; compare legitimacy, support and political aims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Witan, Harold’s coronation and reign
Sub_topics.description: Describe role of the Witan in choosing the king; know Harold Godwinson’s coronation and immediate challenges during his reign.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gate Fulford and Stamford Bridge: reasons and significance of outcomes
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for and significance of outcomes of the battles of Gate Fulford and Stamford Bridge; explain how they affected Harold’s position and the Norman invasion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Battle of Hastings
Sub_topics.description: Know key events of the Battle of Hastings and why it was decisive for control of England.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why William won at Hastings (leadership; troops; tactics)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for William’s victory including leadership skills of Harold and William, strengths/weaknesses of Norman and English troops, and tactics used in the battle.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Submission of the earls (1066)
Sub_topics.description: Know how William established early control through submission of the earls in 1066; explain why this mattered for consolidating rule.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rewarding followers; Marcher earldoms and border control
Sub_topics.description: Explain how William rewarded followers and established control on borderlands through earls; know Marcher earldoms and their purpose/importance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Castles: reasons, features and importance
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for building castles; know key features (motte-and-bailey/stone keeps conceptually) and why castles were vital for control, defence and intimidation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-Saxon resistance: Edwin/Morcar revolt (1068)
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes and outcomes of resistance including revolt of Earls Edwin and Morcar (1068); link to land loss, power struggle and regional opposition.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-Saxon resistance: Edgar Aethling and North (1069)
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes and outcomes of Edgar the Aethling’s role and rebellions in the North (1069); assess significance for William’s response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-Saxon resistance: Hereward the Wake and Ely (1070–71)
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes and outcomes of Hereward the Wake’s rebellion at Ely (1070–71); link to local geography, support and Norman suppression.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Harrying of the North: reasons, features and impacts (1069–87)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and features of the Harrying of the North (1069–70); analyse immediate and long-term impacts from 1069–87 on society, economy and Norman control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Landownership change (1066–87)
Sub_topics.description: Describe changes in landownership from Anglo-Saxon to Norman 1066–87; explain mechanisms (forfeiture, grants) and consequences for power and society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Revolt of the Earls (1075): reasons, events, defeat and effects
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and features of the Revolt of the Earls (1075); describe how it was defeated and analyse its effects on Norman government and control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Feudal hierarchy: tenants-in-chief and knights
Sub_topics.description: Describe the feudal hierarchy after the Conquest; explain roles and importance of tenants-in-chief and knights in governance and military service.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nature of feudalism: landholding, homage, knight service, labour service, forfeiture
Sub_topics.description: Explain feudalism as a system: landholding in return for homage and service (knight service, labour service); understand forfeiture and its role in controlling nobles.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Church and government: Stigand, Lanfranc, Normanisation and reform
Sub_topics.description: Explain the Church’s role in society and relationship to government; know significance of Stigand and Lanfranc; describe Normanisation and reform of the Church under William I.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Extent of change to Anglo-Saxon society and economy
Sub_topics.description: Assess the extent of change to Anglo-Saxon society and economy after the Conquest; consider continuity and transformation in social structure, landholding and local life.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government change: centralised power and limited use of earls
Sub_topics.description: Explain changes to government after the Conquest, including centralised power and limited use of earls under William I; analyse why William preferred this structure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Regents during William’s absences
Sub_topics.description: Describe role of regents during William’s absences and explain what this shows about governance and delegation of authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sheriffs and the demesne
Sub_topics.description: Explain office of sheriff and the demesne; describe their roles in local administration, justice and revenue collection under Norman rule.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Forests: introduction and significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain introduction and significance of the ‘forest’ in Norman England; link to royal authority, law, revenue and social impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Domesday survey/book: purpose and significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain why Domesday survey was conducted and what Domesday Book recorded; analyse significance for Norman government and finance (taxation, control, dispute resolution).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Norman aristocracy: culture and language
Sub_topics.description: Describe culture and language of the Norman aristocracy and explain how this affected society, governance and relations with the English population.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bishop Odo: career and significance
Sub_topics.description: Know career of Bishop Odo and explain his significance in Norman England (power, governance, military involvement) and why he mattered politically.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: William I: character and relations with Robert; Robert’s revolt (1077–80)
Sub_topics.description: Describe character/personality of William I; explain relations with his son Robert including Robert’s revolt in Normandy (1077–80) and its significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: William’s death and disputed succession; William Rufus vs Robert and Odo
Sub_topics.description: Know circumstances of William’s death and resulting disputed succession; explain William Rufus’ position and the defeat of Robert and Odo; analyse consequences for England 1087–88.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Period study and British depth study
Topics.Topic_name: The reigns of King Richard I and King John, 1189–1216

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Feudal hierarchy and feudalism (service and forfeiture)
Sub_topics.description: Describe feudal hierarchy and explain nature of feudalism: landholding, homage, knight service, labour service; understand forfeiture and how it reinforced royal authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Church role and influence
Sub_topics.description: Explain role and influence of the Church in England 1189–1216, including its political, social and economic power and its relationship with the monarchy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nature of kingship: duties, rights and rituals
Sub_topics.description: Explain medieval kingship: duties (justice, defence), rights (revenue, authority) and rituals (coronation, homage); link to expectations of rulers and legitimacy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Richard I: claim, securing power and character
Sub_topics.description: Know Richard I’s claim to the throne, how he secured power, and key aspects of his character; link character to governance style and priorities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: John: claim, securing power, Arthur’s murder and character
Sub_topics.description: Know John’s claim to the throne, how he secured power, and the murder of Prince Arthur; explain how these affected legitimacy and opposition; describe John’s character and its political impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Governing England during Richard’s absence (1189–99)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how England was governed when Richard was absent 1189–99; know key mechanisms/figures of administration and challenges of absentee kingship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government under John’s presence (1199–1216)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how England was governed during John’s continued presence 1199–1216; compare with Richard’s period and link to perceptions of John’s rule.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Royal revenues: demesne and sheriffs
Sub_topics.description: Explain royal revenues from the royal demesne and the role of sheriffs in collecting revenues; link to local governance and corruption/tension.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Feudal incidents, scutage and taxation (1207 tax)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how kings raised money through feudal incidents and scutage; know taxes on moveables and income in 1207 and analyse why financial pressures increased conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Countryside: agriculture and peasant life
Sub_topics.description: Describe countryside life: nature of agriculture and peasant life; link economic structure to obligations, hardship and stability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Towns: life and economic role
Sub_topics.description: Describe life in towns and explain their role in the medieval economy (trade, markets, wealth, taxation) in 1189–1216.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Jews in medieval England: status, moneylending, antisemitism and pogroms (1189–90)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Jews’ legal status and role in moneylending; analyse antisemitism; know causes and extent of pogroms of 1189–90 including significance of Richard I’s coronation; explain royal exploitation through taxation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Crusading concept and English attitudes
Sub_topics.description: Explain concept of crusade and attitudes in England to crusading; link to religion, honour, and politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: English crusading army: who went and why
Sub_topics.description: Describe nature of the English crusading army: who participants were and why they went (religious motives, obligation, ambition, penitence).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Immediate causes of Third Crusade and Richard’s motives
Sub_topics.description: Know immediate causes of the Third Crusade and explain Richard I’s motives for involvement; link to kingship, piety, reputation and politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Richard vs Philip II; victories at Acre and Arsuf
Sub_topics.description: Explain Richard’s quarrel with Philip II and its significance; know key military victories at Acre and Arsuf and analyse why they mattered.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Failure to recapture Jerusalem
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons the crusaders failed to recapture Jerusalem; link to logistics, politics, strategy and the balance of power.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Richard’s return, capture and ransom burden
Sub_topics.description: Know circumstances of Richard’s return from the Holy Land, his capture and the ransom; explain the financial burden on England and its consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Competing aims in Normandy (Richard/John vs Philip II)
Sub_topics.description: Explain competing aims of Richard and John and Philip II in Normandy; link to territorial control, feudal relationships and strategy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chateau Gaillard: cost and importance
Sub_topics.description: Know why Chateau Gaillard was built, its cost and strategic importance; explain how it aimed to secure Normandy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fall of Chateau Gaillard and loss of Normandy (1204)
Sub_topics.description: Explain John’s role and reasons for fall of Chateau Gaillard; know how and why Normandy was lost in 1204 and its significance for John’s authority and finances.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Dispute with the Papacy: causes
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes of John’s dispute with the Papacy; link to appointments, authority and church-state relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Interdict and everyday life impact
Sub_topics.description: Describe what an Interdict involved and explain its impact on everyday life in England (religious services, burials, morale) and political consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reconciliation with Innocent III: significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of reconciliation between John and Pope Innocent III; link to legitimacy, political support and international position.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Financial impositions and arbitrary power; plot of 1212
Sub_topics.description: Explain worsening relations with barons due to financial impositions (taxation, fines) to fund war with France and John’s arbitrary power; know the plot of 1212 and its significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Failure to regain Normandy (1214) and its impact
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of John’s failure to regain Normandy in 1214 on baronial loyalty, finances and political crisis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rebellion of 1215: Northampton, Lincoln and march on London
Sub_topics.description: Know key events of baronial rebellion in 1215 including Northampton, Lincoln and the march on London; explain why these were significant turning points.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Runnymede and Magna Carta: motives and main provisions
Sub_topics.description: Explain motives of John and the barons at Runnymede; know main provisions of Magna Carta and what they aimed to limit/protect; link to rule of law and feudal rights.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First Barons’ War: causes and key events (Rochester; Prince Louis invasion)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for outbreak of the First Barons’ War; know the siege and taking of Rochester and the invasion of Prince Louis; analyse how conflict escalated.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: England in 1216: condition at John’s death and succession problem
Sub_topics.description: Describe condition of England at John’s death; explain the problem of succession and why stability was threatened.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: William Marshal as Protector
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of William Marshal as Protector in 1216 and how he helped address civil war and secure the monarchy.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Period study and British depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: England in 1509; Henry’s accession
Sub_topics.description: Know key features of England in 1509 (society and government) and explain Henry VIII’s accession and early context for his rule.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Henry as Renaissance Prince: character, sovereignty, personal rule
Sub_topics.description: Explain Henry’s character and views on sovereignty/monarchy; describe his personal style of government and what made him a ‘Renaissance Prince’.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Henry’s strengths, weaknesses and aims as monarch
Sub_topics.description: Assess Henry’s strengths, weaknesses and aims as king; link to finance, war, succession, religion and authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wolsey’s rise: reasons, personality, roles and wealth
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Wolsey’s rise to power; describe his personality, roles (e.g., ministerial/church positions) and wealth, and why these mattered for government.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wolsey’s domestic reforms: enclosures, finance and justice
Sub_topics.description: Describe Wolsey’s reforms on enclosures, finance and justice; explain aims, methods and effectiveness, and reactions from elites/common people.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Eltham Ordinances
Sub_topics.description: Know what the Eltham Ordinances were and explain their purpose/significance for reforming the royal household and government efficiency.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Amicable Grant: reasons and reactions
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for the Amicable Grant and analyse reactions/opposition; link to taxation, war finance and Wolsey’s fall in popularity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wolsey’s foreign policy aims
Sub_topics.description: Explain aims of Wolsey’s foreign policy (e.g., security, prestige, balance of power, papal influence) and how they aligned with Henry’s ambitions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Treaty of London (1518)
Sub_topics.description: Know the Treaty of London (1518) and explain why it was significant for diplomacy, peace-making and Wolsey’s reputation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Field of the Cloth of Gold (1520)
Sub_topics.description: Know the Field of the Cloth of Gold (1520) and explain its purposes and significance (display, diplomacy, rivalry with France/Empire).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Foreign policy successes/failures and difficulties in the 1520s
Sub_topics.description: Assess successes and failures of Wolsey’s foreign policy including relations with France and the Holy Roman Empire; explain increasing difficulties in the 1520s and consequences for Wolsey’s position.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Catherine of Aragon and the succession problem
Sub_topics.description: Explain Catherine of Aragon’s role and the succession issue; link to dynastic security and political stability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Henry’s reasons for annulment and attempts to secure it
Sub_topics.description: Explain Henry’s reasons for seeking an annulment and describe attempts to gain it through legal/religious channels; link to heir, ‘King’s Great Matter’ and legitimacy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Opposition to annulment: Pope Clement VII
Sub_topics.description: Explain opposition to annulment, including Pope Clement VII’s role and constraints; link to international politics and papal authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wolsey’s fall: failure of divorce proceedings and Boleyn influence
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Wolsey’s fall, including failure of divorce proceedings in London and influence of the Boleyns; analyse how court factions affected power.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cromwell’s early career and rise (service to Wolsey; MP; Royal Council)
Sub_topics.description: Describe Cromwell’s personality and early career including service to Wolsey, election as MP and membership of the Royal Council; explain why these helped his rise.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cromwell and the annulment; influence over Henry; Chief Minister role
Sub_topics.description: Explain how Cromwell handled the king’s annulment and gained influence over Henry; describe his role as Chief Minister and how he exercised power.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fall of Anne Boleyn (Cromwell’s role)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for the fall of Anne Boleyn, including Cromwell’s role; link to faction, succession and Henry’s aims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Marriage to Jane Seymour: reasons, influence, heir and death
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for marriage to Jane Seymour; describe her influence, the birth of an heir, and her death; link to succession and court politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Marriage to Anne of Cleves: reasons
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Henry’s marriage to Anne of Cleves; link to foreign policy and Protestant alliances.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government and finance reforms under Cromwell
Sub_topics.description: Describe Cromwell’s reform of government and royal finance; explain how administration changed (institutions, revenue collection) and why it strengthened royal control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Parliament management and use
Sub_topics.description: Explain how Cromwell managed and used Parliament to pass major changes; link to Reformation legislation and governance transformation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cromwell’s fall (1540): Norfolk faction and Cleves marriage failure
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Cromwell’s fall in 1540, including influence of the Duke of Norfolk and failure of the marriage to Anne of Cleves; link to factional rivalry and policy failures.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Henry as Defender of the Faith; reasons for campaign against Pope/Church (1529–33)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Henry’s status as ‘Defender of the Faith’ and why he campaigned against the Pope and Catholic Church 1529–33; link to annulment, sovereignty and finance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Act of Succession and Act of Supremacy (1534): significance
Sub_topics.description: Know the Act of Succession and Act of Supremacy (1534); explain their significance for the break with Rome and establishment of royal supremacy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Enforcement of royal supremacy: oaths and treason laws (Cromwell’s role)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Cromwell’s role enforcing the break with Rome through oaths and treason laws; analyse how enforcement removed opposition and strengthened state power.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Opposition: Elizabeth Barton and John Fisher
