Sub_topics.description: Know Elizabeth Barton (Nun of Kent) and John Fisher as opponents; explain their actions and significance for resistance to Reformation policies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thomas More: significance of opposition
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of opposition from Thomas More; link to conscience, law and the limits of dissent under Henry.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact on the English Church: Cranmer and Cromwell influence
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of Reformation on the English Church including role of Thomas Cranmer and influence of Thomas Cromwell; link to doctrine, organisation and authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Monasteries in local communities: roles
Sub_topics.description: Describe role of religious houses/monasteries in local communities (charity, education, healthcare, economy, spiritual life) to understand what was lost/changed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reasons for dissolution: Cromwell’s commissions (1535)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for dissolution of monasteries, including findings of Cromwell’s commissions of 1535; link to finance, power, reforming zeal and control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of dissolution: beneficiaries and losers
Sub_topics.description: Analyse impact of the dissolutions, identifying beneficiaries and losers; consider land redistribution, social welfare effects, and royal finances.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pilgrimage of Grace (1536): reasons
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for the Pilgrimage of Grace uprising (religious, economic, political grievances) and why it gained support.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pilgrimage of Grace: key events (Lincolnshire/Yorkshire) and leaders (Aske; Norfolk)
Sub_topics.description: Know key events including rebellions in Lincolnshire and Yorkshire; explain roles of Robert Aske and the Duke of Norfolk; analyse why the rebellion failed and its significance.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Period study and British depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elizabethan England in 1558: society and government
Sub_topics.description: Know key features of society and government in 1558 and explain conditions Elizabeth inherited at accession.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Legitimacy, gender and marriage problem; Elizabeth’s character/strengths
Sub_topics.description: Explain issues of Elizabeth’s legitimacy, gender expectations and the marriage/succession problem; describe Elizabeth’s character and strengths in ruling.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Challenges: financial weakness, religious divisions and French threat
Sub_topics.description: Explain key challenges at home and abroad on accession: financial weaknesses, religious divisions, and the French threat; link to foreign policy and internal stability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elizabeth’s Religious Settlement (1559): features and impact
Sub_topics.description: Know features of the 1559 Religious Settlement and explain its impact; include key legislation/compromises and how it aimed to create stability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Church of England role in society
Sub_topics.description: Explain the role of the Church of England in society (social control, local life, governance links) and why it mattered for Elizabeth’s rule.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Puritan challenge: nature and extent
Sub_topics.description: Explain nature and extent of the Puritan challenge to the settlement; link to desired reforms, pressure in Parliament/church and Elizabeth’s response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Catholic challenge: nobility, Papacy and foreign powers
Sub_topics.description: Explain nature and extent of Catholic challenge including roles of nobility, Papacy and foreign powers; link to plots, rebellion and international threats.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mary, Queen of Scots: claim to the English throne
Sub_topics.description: Explain Mary Queen of Scots’ claim and why it threatened Elizabeth; link to succession politics and religion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elizabeth and Mary relations (1568–69)
Sub_topics.description: Know key developments in relations between Elizabeth and Mary 1568–69 and how they contributed to later plots and policy decisions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Revolt of the Northern Earls (1569–70): reasons and significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for the Revolt of the Northern Earls and assess its significance for Elizabeth’s security, Catholic threat and government response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ridolfi, Throckmorton and Babington plots; Walsingham and spies
Sub_topics.description: Know features and significance of Ridolfi, Throckmorton and Babington plots; explain Walsingham’s role and use of spies/intelligence in uncovering threats.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Execution of Mary Queen of Scots (1587): reasons and significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Mary’s execution in 1587 and assess its significance for internal security and relations with Catholic powers (especially Spain).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rivalry with Spain: political, religious and commercial
Sub_topics.description: Explain political, religious and commercial rivalry with Spain; link to Protestant-Catholic conflict, trade, empire and security.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Privateering and Drake’s significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of privateering and Drake’s activities; link to wealth, provocation of Spain and naval warfare.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Netherlands involvement and Dudley’s actions: causes of war (1585–88)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for deteriorating relations with Spain including English involvement in the Netherlands and actions of Robert Dudley; link to outbreak of war.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Drake’s raid on Cadiz (‘Singeing the King of Spain’s beard’)
Sub_topics.description: Know Drake’s raid on Cadiz and explain its significance for Spanish preparations, English morale and escalation toward Armada conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Spanish Armada: invasion plans and key events
Sub_topics.description: Describe Spanish invasion plans and key events of the Armada campaign; know sequence of encounters and strategic aims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reasons for English victory over the Armada
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for English victory (tactics, ships, leadership, weather, logistics); evaluate relative importance of factors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Education in home and schools
Sub_topics.description: Describe education in the home and schools in Elizabethan England; link to class, gender and opportunities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Leisure: sport, pastimes and theatre
Sub_topics.description: Describe Elizabethan leisure including sport, pastimes and theatre; explain social significance and differences by class/region.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Causes of increasing poverty and vagabondage
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for increase in poverty and vagabondage during 1558–88; link to population, inflation, enclosure and employment changes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing attitudes and policies towards the poor
Sub_topics.description: Explain changing attitudes and policies towards the poor (poor laws, punishment/relief balance); analyse why policy developed and its effectiveness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Factors prompting exploration: ship/sailing technology and expanding trade
Sub_topics.description: Explain factors prompting exploration including new technology in ships/sailing and drive to expand trade; link to competition, wealth and national prestige.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Drake’s circumnavigation: reasons and significance
Sub_topics.description: Know reasons for Drake’s circumnavigation and explain its significance for trade, knowledge, rivalry with Spain and national pride.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Attempted colonisation of Virginia: reasons and Raleigh’s significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for attempted colonisation of Virginia and significance of Raleigh; link to empire, trade, privateering and settlement aims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Failure of the first Virginia settlement
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for failure of the first Virginia settlement; consider supply, conflict, leadership, environment and planning.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Period study and British depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Spain c1490: crusading spirit and foreign ambitions
Sub_topics.description: Explain Spain’s context c1490 including crusading spirit and foreign ambitions; link to Reconquista legacy, religion and expansion aims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Columbus seeks sponsorship; Queen Isabella’s role and motives
Sub_topics.description: Know Columbus’s attempts to gain sponsorship; explain Queen Isabella’s role and motives (spread Christianity) in supporting Columbus.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Columbus’s first voyage (1492) and problems encountered
Sub_topics.description: Describe Columbus’s 1492 voyage and problems encountered (navigation, supplies, crew, uncertainty) and how these shaped outcomes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Columbus’s actions: Bahamas/Caribbean exploration; La Navidad
Sub_topics.description: Know Columbus’s actions exploring the Bahamas and Caribbean; explain foundation of La Navidad and its significance for early settlement and relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Contact with Indigenous peoples: gold and relations with Tainos/Caribs
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of contact with Indigenous peoples including discovery of gold and relations with Tainos and Caribs; analyse early patterns of cooperation, violence and exploitation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rivalry with Portugal and Treaty of Tordesillas (1494)
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of rivalry with Portugal and significance of Treaty of Tordesillas (1494) in dividing spheres of influence and shaping exploration/claims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Later voyages; Columbus as governor; Santo Domingo (1496) significance
Sub_topics.description: Describe Columbus’s later voyages and role as governor; explain significance of establishment of Spanish colony at Santo Domingo (1496) for empire-building.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Effects of Spanish settlement: treatment of Indigenous peoples and smallpox
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects of Spanish settlement including treatment of Indigenous peoples and effects of smallpox; analyse demographic/social consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Imperial policy in Caribbean: regulation, trade monopoly, authority extension, slavery and missionaries
Sub_topics.description: Explain development of Spanish imperial policy: regulation of exploration, monopoly on trade, extension of Spanish authority, use of slavery; describe role of Catholic missionaries and religious goals.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Balboa claims Pacific (1513)
Sub_topics.description: Know Balboa’s claim of Spanish authority over the Pacific (1513) and explain its significance for imperial ambition and exploration.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conquest of Cuba
Sub_topics.description: Describe the conquest of Cuba and explain why it was important for Spanish expansion, bases and wealth.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magellan voyage and claim to the Philippines
Sub_topics.description: Know voyage of Magellan and explain significance of Spanish claim to the Philippines for global empire and trade routes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cortés expedition to Mexico (1519)
Sub_topics.description: Describe Cortés’s expedition to Mexico in 1519 and explain motives, preparation and initial contacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conquest of Mexico: Montezuma, Aztecs vs Tlaxcalans, key events
Sub_topics.description: Explain key events of Spanish conquest of Mexico; know role of Montezuma and the war between Aztecs and Tlaxcalans; analyse alliances, technology, disease and strategy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Capture of Tenochtitlan and Aztec surrender
Sub_topics.description: Describe capture of Tenochtitlan and explain why the Aztecs surrendered; link to siege warfare, disease and political divisions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cortés as Governor of New Spain (1523–28)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Cortés’s actions as Governor and Captain-General of New Spain (1523–28); link to administration, exploitation and consolidation of Spanish control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Consequences for the Aztecs
Sub_topics.description: Explain consequences of Spanish invasion for the Aztecs (political collapse, demographic changes, cultural/religious transformation, exploitation).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Spanish base at Panama: founding and significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain founding and significance of Spanish base at Panama for controlling movement, trade and further conquest across the Americas.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First contact with Incas (1528) and death of Huayna Capac
Sub_topics.description: Know contact with the Incas (1528) and explain significance of Huayna Capac’s death for instability and Spanish conquest opportunities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pizarro voyage (1530) and Inca civil war (Atahuallpa vs Huascar)
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Pizarro’s voyage (1530) and the civil war between Atahuallpa and Huascar; link to weakening of Inca resistance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conquest of Peru: Cajamarca, Atahuallpa capture, Inca revolt, siege of Cuzco; impact
Sub_topics.description: Describe key events of Spanish conquest of Peru: Battle of Cajamarca and capture of Atahuallpa; Inca revolt and siege of Cuzco (1536–37); analyse impact of conquest on Inca society and Spanish power.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Viceroys and encomienda system
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of viceroys and encomiendas in governing/exploiting the Spanish Empire; link to control of labour, tribute and colonial administration.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Las Casas and New Laws (1542)
Sub_topics.description: Know Bartolomé de las Casas’ role and explain significance of the New Laws (1542) for Indigenous treatment, encomienda reform and imperial policy debates.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Silver discoveries: Bolivia and Mexico; foundation of La Paz (1548)
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of discovery of silver in Bolivia and Mexico; know foundation of La Paz (1548); analyse effects on economy, labour systems and imperial priorities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gold and silver: importance to Spanish economy and European empire
Sub_topics.description: Explain importance of American gold and silver for Spanish economy and for supporting Spain’s European empire (war finance, inflation/‘price revolution’ conceptually).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Slave trade and goods from the Americas: impact on Spain
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact on Spain of the slave trade and goods from the Americas (new commodities, trade patterns, wealth, moral/political effects).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Imperial government: House of Trade and Council of the Indies
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the Spanish Empire was governed: roles of the House of Trade and Council of the Indies; link to regulation, taxation, legal control and information flow.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Period study and British depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Expansion/immigration and colonial society tensions
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of expansion and immigration on colonial society: settlement patterns and tensions among social groups; link to regional differences and inequality.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Colonial economy: trade with Britain/West Indies; tobacco; piracy
Sub_topics.description: Explain economic developments: trade with Britain and West Indies; importance of tobacco; impact of piracy including activities of ‘Black Sam’ Bellamy and Edward Teach (‘Blackbeard’).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Suppression of piracy: Proclamation and Piracy Act (1717); Governor Spotswood
Sub_topics.description: Know King George I’s Proclamation and the Piracy Act (1717); explain efforts to suppress piracy and role of Governor Spotswood; analyse consequences for trade and security.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Transatlantic slave trade and Atlantic trade triangle
Sub_topics.description: Describe the transatlantic slave trade and the ‘Atlantic trade triangle’; explain how the system operated and its economic drivers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Slavery and plantations: tobacco and rice
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of slavery on development of tobacco and rice plantations; link to labour demands, profitability and expansion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Slavery’s impact on colonial society; fugitives and punishment
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of slavery on colonial society: position and treatment of enslaved people; how colonies treated fugitives; link to laws, violence and racial hierarchy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stono Rebellion (1739) and Spain’s protection of runaways in Florida
Sub_topics.description: Know Stono Rebellion (1739) and explain why it occurred; analyse significance of Spain’s decision to protect runaways in Florida and its effect on rebellion fears and policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: New York Conspiracy (1741)
Sub_topics.description: Describe the New York Conspiracy (1741) and explain its significance for fear, repression and racial tensions in the colonies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Smuggling, customs revenue and fur trade control
Sub_topics.description: Explain problems within the colonies: smuggling; attempts to collect customs revenue; efforts to control the fur trade; link to enforcement, corruption and emerging resentment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Awakening and revivalist preaching
Sub_topics.description: Explain religious revivals including the Great Awakening; describe role of revivalist preachers and impact on colonial identity, authority and social relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Enlightenment: education, newspapers and public libraries
Sub_topics.description: Explain Enlightenment impact: emphasis on education; growth of newspapers and public libraries; analyse how ideas spread and influenced colonial society and politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Benjamin Franklin: writer, philanthropist and intellectual
Sub_topics.description: Know significance of Benjamin Franklin as a writer, philanthropist and intellectual; explain how he embodied Enlightenment values and influenced colonial society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: King George’s War (1744–48): relations with French and Indigenous peoples
Sub_topics.description: Explain relations with French and Indigenous peoples during and after King George’s War (1744–48); link to frontier conflict and alliances.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: French and Indian War (1754–63) and Wolfe in Canada
Sub_topics.description: Describe French and Indian War in North America; explain role of Wolfe in Canada and why the war was decisive for imperial control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Treaty of Paris (1763) and Proclamation Act (1763) significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Treaty of Paris (1763) and Proclamation Act (1763); link to territorial change, Indigenous relations and colonial resentment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: War’s impact on colonist relations with Britain
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the French and Indian War changed American colonists’ relations with Britain; link to cost, control, identity and expectations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Opposition to Sugar Act (1764)
Sub_topics.description: Explain opposition to the Sugar Act (1764); link to taxation, trade regulation and developing protest arguments.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pontiac’s Rebellion (1763–64) and Paxton Boys
Sub_topics.description: Describe relations with Indigenous peoples including Pontiac’s Rebellion (1763–64); explain Paxton Boys’ actions and impact; link to frontier violence and British policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stamp Act opposition; Sons of Liberty; Boston Massacre (1770)
Sub_topics.description: Explain growing opposition to Britain: Stamp Act protests, Sons of Liberty actions, and significance of Boston Massacre (1770) for radicalising opinion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Boston Tea Party (1773) and Intolerable Acts (1774)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Boston Tea Party and British response via Intolerable Acts; analyse significance in escalating conflict and colonial unity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First and Second Continental Congresses (1774–75) significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of the First and Second Continental Congresses for coordination, resistance and movement toward independence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Common Sense, Declaration of Independence and Jefferson
Sub_topics.description: Explain influence of Thomas Paine’s ‘Common Sense’; describe significance of Declaration of Independence and role of Thomas Jefferson; link to ideology and mobilisation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: American victories: Saratoga (1777) and Yorktown (1781)
Sub_topics.description: Know key American victories at Saratoga and Yorktown; explain why they were decisive and how strategy and alliances shaped outcomes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Washington’s role, British mistakes, and French/Spanish involvement
Sub_topics.description: Analyse significance of Washington’s leadership, British mistakes, and French/Spanish involvement in the war; explain how these factors contributed to independence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Peace of Paris (1783) and Franklin
Sub_topics.description: Know Peace of Paris (1783) and explain Franklin’s role; analyse terms and significance for Britain, USA and global politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Independence and slavery: significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of American independence for slavery; consider continuities/changes, contradictions and regional impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Consequences for Indigenous peoples
Sub_topics.description: Explain consequences of the war for Indigenous peoples (land loss, treaty changes, violence, shifting alliances).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact on Loyalists and resettlement (Nova Scotia, Niagara)
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact on Loyalists including persecution, property loss and resettlement in Nova Scotia and Niagara; analyse how independence reshaped populations.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Period study and British depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plains Indigenous social/tribal structures and survival
Sub_topics.description: Describe Indigenous peoples of the Plains: social and tribal structures, ways of life and means of survival; link to environment, buffalo and mobility.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Beliefs about land/nature; attitudes to war and property
Sub_topics.description: Explain Plains Indigenous beliefs about land and nature; attitudes to war and property; contrast with settler/government views to explain conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migration drivers: Oregon Trail (from 1836), Manifest Destiny, Gold Rush (1849)
Sub_topics.description: Explain factors encouraging migration west: Oregon Trail from 1836, belief in Manifest Destiny, and California Gold Rush (1849); link to opportunity, ideology and economics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early migration experiences: Donner Party and Mormon migration (1846–47)
Sub_topics.description: Describe early migration to c1850 including experiences of the Donner Party and Mormon migration 1846–47; explain risks, organisation and hardship of journeys.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early settlement development and problems
Sub_topics.description: Explain development and problems of early settlement (isolation, supply, lawlessness, environment); link to why communities struggled.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tension causes: US policy and ‘Permanent Indian Frontier’
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for tension with Indigenous peoples including US government policy and the ‘Permanent Indian Frontier’; link to expansion pressure and broken promises.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First Fort Laramie Treaty (1851) significance
Sub_topics.description: Know significance of the first Fort Laramie Treaty (1851); explain aims, terms, and why it failed/led to further conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Indian Appropriations Act (1851)
Sub_topics.description: Explain the Indian Appropriations Act (1851) and its significance for reservation policy and US control of Indigenous peoples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lawlessness in early towns and attempts to tackle it
Sub_topics.description: Describe lawlessness in early towns/settlements and explain attempts to tackle it (vigilantes, local law, sheriffs conceptually); link to frontier conditions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Railroads: Pacific Railroad Act (1862), transcontinental completion (1869) and network spread
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of railroads; know Pacific Railroad Act (1862), completion of First Transcontinental Railroad (1869), and spread of rail network; analyse impact on migration, trade and Indigenous peoples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Homestead Act (1862) impact
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of the Homestead Act (1862) on settlement patterns and farming; link to land ownership incentives and conflict with Indigenous peoples/ranchers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Homesteader solutions: new methods/technology; Timber Culture Act (1873)
Sub_topics.description: Explain attempts to solve homesteader problems using new methods/technology; know impact of Timber Culture Act (1873) and why environmental challenges persisted.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Law and order: roles of law officers and increased federal influence
Sub_topics.description: Explain how law and order were introduced in settlements: roles of law officers; increasing federal government influence; link to state-building and control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cattle industry growth and key figures (Iliff, McCoy, Goodnight); Abilene; railroads
Sub_topics.description: Explain factors in growth of cattle industry; know roles of Iliff, McCoy and Goodnight; significance of Abilene and railroads for cattle drives and markets.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cowboy role changes and ranching developments; ranchers vs homesteaders
Sub_topics.description: Describe changing role of the cowboy and changes in ranching; explain relations/conflict between ranchers and homesteaders.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of railroads/cattle/gold on Plains Indigenous peoples
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of railroads, cattle industry and gold prospecting on Plains Indigenous peoples; link to land loss, resource destruction and increased conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reservation policy and Second Fort Laramie Treaty (1868)
Sub_topics.description: Explain US government policy including continued use of reservations; know Second Fort Laramie Treaty (1868) and its significance for Sioux and later conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conflict: Little Crow’s War (1862) and Sand Creek Massacre (1864)
Sub_topics.description: Know Little Crow’s War (1862) and Sand Creek Massacre (1864); explain causes, events and significance in escalating violence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Red Cloud’s War (1866–68) significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Red Cloud’s War (1866–68) for Indigenous resistance and US policy; link to Bozeman Trail, forts and treaty outcomes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Farming changes: new technology and methods
Sub_topics.description: Explain changes in farming in later West, including new technology and new farming methods; link to productivity and settlement sustainability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cattle industry changes: winter 1886–87 and end of open range
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of winter of 1886–87 on cattle industry; analyse how ranching changed and why this led to end of open range.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Continued settlement: Exodusters (Kansas 1879), Oklahoma Land Rush (1893), closure of Indian Frontier
Sub_topics.description: Explain continued settlement movements including Exodusters and Kansas (1879), Oklahoma Land Rush (1893), and closure of the ‘Indian Frontier’; link to policy, racism, opportunity and end of frontier era.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Law and order: sheriffs/marshals; Billy the Kid, Wyatt Earp and OK Corral (1881)
Sub_topics.description: Explain dealing with law and order via sheriffs and marshals; know significance of Billy the Kid, Wyatt Earp and the OK Corral (1881) in frontier justice and myth vs reality.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Range wars: Johnson County War (1892)
Sub_topics.description: Describe range wars including Johnson County War (1892); explain causes (land, fencing, cattle theft accusations) and significance for end of open range.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Little Big Horn (1876) and impact
Sub_topics.description: Know Battle of the Little Big Horn (1876) and explain its impact on US policy, public opinion and subsequent military action against Indigenous peoples.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wounded Knee Massacre (1890)
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes and significance of Wounded Knee Massacre (1890); link to Ghost Dance fears, reservation conditions and final suppression.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Buffalo extermination and consequences
Sub_topics.description: Explain hunting and extermination of the buffalo and why it happened; analyse consequences for Plains Indigenous survival, culture and independence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Life on reservations
Sub_topics.description: Describe Indigenous peoples’ lives on reservations; explain conditions, restrictions, government control and cultural impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changing government attitudes: Dawes Act (1887)
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of changing government attitudes, including Dawes Act (1887); analyse aims (assimilation, allotment) and effects on land ownership and community.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Period study and British depth study
Topics.Topic_name: Superpower relations and the Cold War, 1941–91

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Grand Alliance and wartime conferences: Tehran, Yalta, Potsdam outcomes
Sub_topics.description: Explain the Grand Alliance and know outcomes of Tehran, Yalta and Potsdam conferences; link agreements/disagreements to post-war tensions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ideological differences and leaders’ attitudes (Stalin, Truman, Churchill)
Sub_topics.description: Explain ideological differences between the superpowers and analyse attitudes of Stalin, Truman and Churchill; link to mistrust and competing aims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic bomb and early Cold War documents; satellite states
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of development of the atomic bomb on relations; know significance of the Long and Novikov telegrams; explain creation of Soviet satellite states in Eastern Europe and how this affected tensions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Truman Doctrine and Marshall Plan (1947) impact
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of Truman Doctrine and Marshall Plan (1947) on US-Soviet relations; link to containment, economic aid and ideological conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cominform (1947), Comecon (1949) and NATO (1949) significance
Sub_topics.description: Know significance of Cominform, Comecon and formation of NATO; explain how they institutionalised division and escalated Cold War.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Berlin division and Berlin Crisis (1948–49) blockade/airlift; FRG/GDR formation
Sub_topics.description: Explain Berlin’s division into zones; describe Berlin Crisis (blockade and airlift) and its impact; explain formation of Federal Republic of Germany and German Democratic Republic and significance for Europe.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Arms race significance and Warsaw Pact formation
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of the arms race; know formation of the Warsaw Pact and how it deepened military division in Europe.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hungarian Uprising (1956): causes/events and Khrushchev’s response
Sub_topics.description: Explain events leading to Hungarian Uprising (1956) and Khrushchev’s response; link to Soviet control and limits of reform.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: International reaction to Soviet invasion of Hungary
Sub_topics.description: Explain international reaction to Soviet invasion of Hungary and why response was limited; link to Cold War priorities and Suez context (conceptually).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Berlin refugee problem, Berlin ultimatum (1958) and summits (1959–61)
Sub_topics.description: Explain refugee problem in Berlin; know Khrushchev’s Berlin ultimatum (1958) and significance of summit meetings 1959–61 for tension and negotiations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cuban Revolution: US refusal to recognise Castro; closer USSR ties; Bay of Pigs significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of Cuban Revolution on relations: US refusal to recognise Castro, Cuba’s closer ties with USSR, and significance of Bay of Pigs incident; link to Cold War in Americas.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prague Spring: opposition to Soviet control
Sub_topics.description: Explain opposition in Czechoslovakia culminating in Prague Spring; link to reform demands and Soviet reaction context.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Berlin Wall construction (1961)
Sub_topics.description: Explain why and how the Berlin Wall was constructed in 1961; analyse immediate and longer-term significance for East-West relations and Berlin refugees.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cuban Missile Crisis: events
Sub_topics.description: Describe key events of the Cuban Missile Crisis; explain escalation, decision-making and brinkmanship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Brezhnev Doctrine and re-establishing Soviet control in Czechoslovakia
Sub_topics.description: Explain Brezhnev Doctrine and how Soviet control was re-established in Czechoslovakia; link to justification for intervention and limits on sovereignty.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of Berlin Wall and Kennedy’s 1963 visit
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of Berlin Wall on US-Soviet relations; know significance of Kennedy’s visit to West Berlin (1963).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cuban Missile Crisis consequences: hotline and arms control treaties
Sub_topics.description: Explain consequences of Cuban Missile Crisis including establishment of the ‘hotline’; describe attempts at arms control: Limited Test Ban Treaty (1963), Outer Space Treaty (1967), Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (1968) and their significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: International reaction to Soviet measures in Czechoslovakia
Sub_topics.description: Explain international reaction to Soviet intervention in Czechoslovakia and why responses differed; link to Cold War context.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Détente and significance of SALT 1, Helsinki Accords, SALT 2
Sub_topics.description: Explain détente and attempts to reduce tensions in 1970s; know significance of SALT 1, Helsinki Accords and SALT 2 as arms control/relations milestones.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Afghanistan invasion, Carter Doctrine and Olympic boycotts
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, Carter Doctrine and Olympic boycotts; analyse how these ended détente and escalated ‘Second Cold War’.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reagan and Second Cold War; SDI
Sub_topics.description: Explain Reagan’s role in the ‘Second Cold War’ including Strategic Defence Initiative (SDI); analyse how policies increased pressure on USSR.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reagan and Gorbachev: reducing tensions
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Reagan and Gorbachev in reducing tensions; link to summits, negotiation and changing Soviet policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gorbachev’s ‘new thinking’ and loosening Soviet grip on Eastern Europe
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of Gorbachev’s ‘new thinking’ on Eastern Europe and how it loosened Soviet control; link to reforms and non-intervention.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fall of the Berlin Wall significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of fall of the Berlin Wall for Germany, Eastern Europe and end of Cold War division.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Collapse of Soviet Union and end of Warsaw Pact
Sub_topics.description: Explain collapse of the Soviet Union and its significance in ending the Warsaw Pact and the Cold War; link to political/economic pressures and independence movements.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Period study and British depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: British Mandate: conflicting Jewish and Arab interests
Sub_topics.description: Explain conflicting interests and demands of Jews and Arabs within the British Mandate; link to immigration, land, nationalism and British policy constraints.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: End of Mandate and creation of Israel: King David Hotel bombing and UN Resolution 181
Sub_topics.description: Explain key events leading to end of British Mandate, partition and creation of Israel; know significance of King David Hotel bombing and UN Resolution 181; analyse how these accelerated withdrawal/partition.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Arab-Israeli War (1948–49): key events
Sub_topics.description: Describe key events of the Arab-Israeli war (1948–49) and explain why war broke out and how outcomes shaped the region.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Territorial changes and Palestinian refugee status
Sub_topics.description: Explain territorial changes after 1948–49 and their impact; describe refugee status of Palestinian Arabs and why it became a lasting issue.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: IDF creation, Law of Return and US aid
Sub_topics.description: Explain creation of Israeli Defence Forces and Law of Return; analyse significance of US aid to Israel for security and regional tensions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Israel–Egypt relations after 1949
Sub_topics.description: Explain Israel’s relations with Egypt in early period and why this relationship was central to conflict escalation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nasser and Egypt’s leadership of Arab world
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nasser’s role and Egypt’s leadership in Arab world; link to pan-Arabism, Cold War alignment and anti-imperialism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Israeli attacks on Gaza (1955) and Sinai (1956) significance
Sub_topics.description: Know events and significance of Israeli attacks on Gaza (1955) and Sinai (1956); link to fedayeen raids, security dilemmas and escalation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Suez Crisis (1956) and UAR formation (1958)
Sub_topics.description: Explain events and significance of Suez Crisis (1956); link to Britain/France/Israel actions, US/USSR roles; know formation of UAR (1958) and why it mattered for Arab politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cairo Conference (1964) and escalating tension (Syria/Fatah; Samu raid; 7 April 1967)
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Cairo Conference (1964); describe escalating tensions between Israel, Syria and Jordan including Syria’s support for Fatah, Israel’s raid on Samu and events of 7 April 1967.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: USSR, Nasser and USA actions leading to Six Day War
Sub_topics.description: Explain actions of USSR, Nasser and USA in period leading to Six Day War; analyse how miscalculation and alliances contributed to war.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Six Day War (1967): key events
Sub_topics.description: Describe key events of the Six Day War (1967) and explain how Israel achieved rapid victory and what changed militarily/territorially.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: UN Resolution 242 and Suez Canal dispute
Sub_topics.description: Explain UN Resolution 242 and continued dispute over Suez Canal; link to land for peace, recognition and ongoing conflict drivers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Occupied territories and their significance (Golan, Gaza, West Bank, Sinai, East Jerusalem)
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of occupied territories after 1967: Golan Heights, Gaza Strip, West Bank, Sinai and East Jerusalem; analyse how occupation shaped refugees, security, settlements and diplomacy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Terrorism and responses: PFLP hijacks (1970), Black September/Munich, expulsion of PLO from Jordan (1970)
Sub_topics.description: Explain use of terrorism and Israel’s response and international attitudes: know PFLP airplane hijacks (1970), Black September and Munich Olympics; explain expulsion of the PLO from Jordan (1970) and its significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Egyptian relations with Israel/USA/USSR/Arab states (1967–73)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Egyptian relations with Israel, USA, USSR and other Arab states 1967–73; link to diplomacy and preparation for renewed conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Israel consolidates control of occupied territories
Sub_topics.description: Explain how Israel consolidated control of occupied territories (administration, security, settlements conceptually) and why this affected negotiations and resistance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Yom Kippur War (1973) and aftermath
Sub_topics.description: Describe key events of the Yom Kippur War (1973) and its aftermath; analyse how it changed diplomacy, superpower involvement and regional power balance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oil crisis and superpower involvement; Kissinger shuttle diplomacy; Suez reopening
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of oil crisis and involvement of USA/USSR; describe Kissinger’s ‘shuttle diplomacy’ and reopening of Suez Canal; link to leverage and negotiation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sadat/Begin visits; Carter; Camp David (1978) and Treaty of Washington (1979)
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Sadat’s visit to Israel (1977), Begin’s visit to Egypt (1977), President Carter’s role, Camp David Accords (1978) and Treaty of Washington (1979); analyse why they were breakthroughs.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Arafat UN speech (1974) and PLO in Lebanon
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Arafat’s speech to the UN (1974) and PLO activities in Lebanon; link to international recognition and conflict spread.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Israeli reprisals and invasion of Lebanon (1982): results
Sub_topics.description: Describe Israeli reprisals and 1982 invasion of Lebanon and explain results; link to security aims, regional destabilisation and Palestinian issue.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First Intifada (1987–93) in occupied territories
Sub_topics.description: Explain Israeli occupied territories and the First Palestinian Intifada (1987–93): causes, nature of uprising and significance for diplomacy and public opinion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Arafat renounces terrorism (1988) significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Arafat’s renunciation of terrorism in a UN speech (1988) and how it affected negotiation possibilities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gulf War (1991) and end of Cold War: changing superpower policies
Sub_topics.description: Explain how US involvement in Gulf War (1991) and end of Cold War changed superpower policies and opportunities for Middle East peace processes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Oslo Accords and aftermath: PNA, Israel–Jordan treaty (1994), Oslo II (1995)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Oslo Accords (1993) and roles of Arafat and Rabin; describe setting up of Palestinian National Authority, Israel–Jordan peace treaty (1994), and Oslo II (1995); analyse why progress was limited/contested.

Topics.Strand: Paper 3: Modern depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Opposition to Tsar: peasants and workers in early 1917
Sub_topics.description: Explain growth of opposition to the Tsar among peasants and town workers in early 1917; link grievances to shortages, inequality and political repression.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: WWI impact on Russia: defeats and economic/political/social effects; Tsar as commander
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of First World War on Russia: military defeats and economic, political and social effects; analyse significance of Tsar becoming commander-in-chief for blame and legitimacy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: February Revolution: Petrograd events, strikes and army mutiny; abdication
Sub_topics.description: Explain immediate reasons for February Revolution: events in Petrograd including strikes and army mutiny; explain Tsar’s absence and abdication and why authority collapsed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Provisional Government: establishment, Dual Control and Order No.1; Kerensky
Sub_topics.description: Describe establishment of Provisional Government; explain problems it faced including Dual Control and Soviet Order Number 1; know Kerensky’s role and significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weaknesses/failures of the Provisional Government
Sub_topics.description: Explain weaknesses and failures of Provisional Government (war continuation, land/food issues, authority challenges) and why it lost support.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kornilov Revolt significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of the Kornilov Revolt for undermining the Provisional Government and increasing Bolshevik credibility/arming of workers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lenin’s return: April Theses and growing Bolshevik support; July Days
Sub_topics.description: Explain Lenin’s return and activities including April Theses and growth of Bolshevik support; describe July Days and their significance for power struggle.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: October Revolution: Bolshevik seizure of power; reasons for success; Trotsky and Lenin roles
Sub_topics.description: Describe Bolshevik seizure of power in October 1917; explain reasons for success; analyse roles of Trotsky and Lenin in planning and leadership.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early Bolshevik decrees (Nov–Dec 1917)
Sub_topics.description: Know early Bolshevik decrees of November–December 1917 (e.g., land, peace, workers’ control conceptually) and explain how they aimed to consolidate support and transform society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Removing opposition: Constituent Assembly and execution of Tsar’s family
Sub_topics.description: Explain removal of opposition including dispersal of Constituent Assembly and execution of Tsar Nicholas II and his family; analyse how these actions signalled dictatorship and civil war escalation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Treaty of Brest-Litovsk: reasons, terms, significance and reactions
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Treaty of Brest-Litovsk; know main terms and significance; describe different reactions within Russia (support, opposition, impact on legitimacy) and how it influenced civil war.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Civil War: reasons, key events and effects (1918–21)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for, key events of and effects of the Civil War 1918–21; link to political division, foreign intervention and social/economic collapse.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why Bolsheviks won: strengths, Trotsky, foreign intervention and White weaknesses
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Bolshevik victory including strengths (organisation, propaganda, control), role of Trotsky, effect of foreign intervention, and weaknesses/divisions of the Whites.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Red Terror, Cheka and Kronstadt Mutiny
Sub_topics.description: Explain Red Terror and role of the Cheka; know Kronstadt Mutiny and its significance for internal opposition and policy change toward NEP.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Centralisation: Lenin, Politburo and formation of USSR
Sub_topics.description: Explain Bolshevik centralisation including roles of Lenin and Politburo; explain setting up of the USSR and how it strengthened one-party control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: War Communism: reasons, features and unpopularity
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and features of War Communism; analyse why it was unpopular and its effects on economy, peasantry and urban workers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: NEP: reasons, features, reactions and economic effects (1921–24)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and features of the New Economic Policy; describe different reactions; analyse effects on the economy 1921–24 and implications for socialism debate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Social changes under Bolsheviks: women, education and culture
Sub_topics.description: Explain social changes 1918–24 including impact of Bolshevik policies on women, education and culture; link to ideology and practical constraints.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stalin vs rivals: strengths and weaknesses (Trotsky, Kamenev, Zinoviev, Bukharin)
Sub_topics.description: Compare strengths and weaknesses of Stalin and key rivals; explain political positions, personalities and support bases in leadership struggle 1924–28.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why Stalin emerged as leader (1924–28)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons Stalin emerged as leader including methods of removing rivals 1924–28 (alliances, party control, ideology debates); link to role as General Secretary and political manoeuvring.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Purges: reasons, nature and consequences; armed forces purges
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for, nature of and consequences of 1930s purges; include purges of the armed forces and how they affected society, loyalty and USSR security.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: NKVD and labour camps (Gulag): use and conditions
Sub_topics.description: Explain work of secret police (NKVD); describe use of labour camps and conditions; analyse how terror controlled society and supported industrial projects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Show trials (1936–38): reasons and importance
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and importance of show trials 1936–38; link to propaganda, eliminating opposition and creating fear/confessions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Official culture: socialist realism; control of education and religion; censorship
Sub_topics.description: Explain Stalinist propaganda/censorship: official culture and socialist realism; control of education and religion; media censorship and how they shaped beliefs and loyalty.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Constitution of 1936
Sub_topics.description: Know features of the 1936 Constitution and explain its purpose/significance (appearance of democracy vs reality of dictatorship).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cult of Stalin: meaning and reasons
Sub_topics.description: Explain meaning of the Cult of Stalin and reasons for its introduction; link to legitimacy, unity, fear and ideological control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: How the Cult of Stalin was achieved
Sub_topics.description: Explain methods used to achieve the Cult of Stalin (media, education, imagery, rewriting history, public rituals) and their effects on society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why Stalin collectivised agriculture (problems of NEP)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Stalin’s reasons for changing agriculture, including problems of NEP and desire for grain supply/control and funding for industrialisation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Collectivisation: organisation, mechanisation, opposition, kulaks and Ukraine famine
Sub_topics.description: Describe organisation of collectives, mechanisation; explain widespread opposition and attack on kulaks; explain famine in Ukraine and its causes/consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Collectivisation: successes and failures
Sub_topics.description: Assess successes and failures of collectivisation in terms of output, control, human cost and long-term agricultural performance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Industrialisation motives and NEP failings
Sub_topics.description: Explain Stalin’s motives for rapid industrialisation, including perceived failings of NEP; link to defence, ideology and power.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gosplan, Five-Year Plans and Stakhanovite Movement
Sub_topics.description: Explain roles of Gosplan, Five-Year Plans and Stakhanovite Movement; describe targets, methods and how workers were mobilised/incentivised.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Industrialisation: successes and failures
Sub_topics.description: Assess successes and failures of industrialisation (production gains, living standards, inefficiency, human cost) and its impact on USSR strength.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Living and working conditions in towns and countryside
Sub_topics.description: Describe living/working conditions in towns and countryside under Stalin; link to housing, wages, rationing, discipline and peasant hardship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Different experiences of social groups
Sub_topics.description: Explain differing experiences of social groups (workers, peasants, elites, party members) and how policy/terror created inequality and privilege.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Women: family life, employment and political position changes
Sub_topics.description: Explain changes in family life, employment and political position of women under Stalin; link to ideology, workforce needs and later conservative family policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Persecution of ethnic minorities: reasons and features
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and features of persecution of ethnic minorities; link to security fears, nationalism, deportations and control.

Topics.Strand: Paper 3: Modern depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Germany 1918: unrest, Kaiser abdication, armistice and new republic
Sub_topics.description: Explain situation in Germany at end of WWI: political unrest, abdication of Kaiser, armistice and creation of a new republic; link to war weariness and revolution fears.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weimar Constitution: strengths and weaknesses
Sub_topics.description: Describe key features of Weimar Constitution; explain strengths (democracy, rights) and weaknesses (proportional representation, Article 48, coalition instability) and how these affected stability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why Weimar was unpopular: stab-in-the-back and Versailles terms
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for early unpopularity including ‘stab in the back’ theory and key terms of Treaty of Versailles; link to legitimacy crisis and resentment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Left and Right challenges: Spartacists, Freikorps, Kapp Putsch
Sub_topics.description: Explain challenges from Left and Right: Spartacist uprising, role of Freikorps, and Kapp Putsch; analyse why threats emerged and how government responded.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1923 crises: hyperinflation and Ruhr occupation (reasons/effects)
Sub_topics.description: Explain challenges of 1923: causes/effects of hyperinflation; reasons for and effects of French occupation of the Ruhr; link to passive resistance and economic collapse.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Recovery: Stresemann, Rentenmark, Dawes/Young Plans, US loans
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for economic recovery 1924–29: Stresemann’s actions, Rentenmark, Dawes and Young Plans, and American loans/investment; evaluate stability achieved.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: International acceptance: Locarno and League of Nations
Sub_topics.description: Explain Stresemann’s achievements gaining international acceptance: Locarno Pact and joining the League of Nations; analyse significance for Germany’s status and security.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Standard of living changes (Golden Years)
Sub_topics.description: Describe changes in standard of living 1924–29; explain who benefited and remaining weaknesses in the economy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Women’s position changes: work, politics, leisure
Sub_topics.description: Explain changes in position of women in work, politics and leisure during 1924–29; link to ‘New Woman’ debates and social attitudes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cultural changes: architecture, art and cinema
Sub_topics.description: Describe cultural changes in Weimar Germany including developments in architecture, art and cinema; explain why culture became experimental and contested.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hitler early career and creation of Nazi Party (1919–20)
Sub_topics.description: Know Hitler’s early career: joining German Workers’ Party and setting up Nazi Party 1919–20; explain conditions that enabled extremist politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Twenty-Five Point Programme
Sub_topics.description: Describe key aims of Twenty-Five Point Programme and explain how it appealed to different groups and defined Nazi ideology.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: SA role
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of SA in Nazi Party development: intimidation, recruitment, propaganda and street violence; link to party growth and public image.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Munich Putsch: reasons, events and consequences; Mein Kampf
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for, events and consequences of Munich Putsch; know significance of Mein Kampf for ideology and strategy shift.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Limited Nazi support (1924–28) and party reorganisation; Bamberg Conference (1926)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for limited Nazi support 1924–28; describe party reorganisation including Bamberg Conference (1926) and how strategy broadened appeal.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Unemployment: causes/impact; Communist growth
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes and impact of unemployment after 1929; explain growth of support for Communist Party and how crisis polarised politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why Nazi support grew (1929–32): Hitler appeal, propaganda, SA
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for growth in Nazi support including Hitler’s appeal, effectiveness of propaganda, and SA activities; link to fear, nationalism and scapegoating.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1932 elections and why Hitler became Chancellor (Hindenburg and von Papen)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Presidential and Reichstag elections of 1932; analyse reasons Hitler became Chancellor in 1933 including roles of Hindenburg and von Papen and elite miscalculation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reichstag Fire and Enabling Act; banning parties/unions
Sub_topics.description: Explain Reichstag Fire and how Nazis used it; describe Enabling Act and banning of other parties and trade unions; analyse how legal steps created dictatorship.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Night of the Long Knives and threat from Röhm/SA
Sub_topics.description: Explain threat from Röhm and SA; describe Night of the Long Knives and its significance for consolidating Hitler’s power and gaining army support.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hindenburg’s death; Hitler as Führer; army oath
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Hindenburg’s death; Hitler becoming Führer; army oath of allegiance and how it secured military loyalty.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gestapo, SS and concentration camps
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of Gestapo and SS and use of concentration camps in enforcing Nazi police state; link to surveillance, terror and eliminating opposition.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Control of the legal system
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nazi control of legal system (courts, judges, special courts) and how it removed rule-of-law protections.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Goebbels and propaganda: censorship, media, rallies, sport, Berlin Olympics (1936)
Sub_topics.description: Explain role of Goebbels and Ministry of Propaganda: censorship, media manipulation, rallies and sport; know Berlin Olympics (1936) and how it was used to project Nazi image.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Control of culture and arts
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nazi control of culture and arts (art, architecture, literature, film); link to ideology, censorship and promoting Aryan values.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Church control: Concordat and Reich Church
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nazi attempts to control Catholic and Protestant Churches, including Concordat and Reich Church; analyse success/limits and reasons for compromise/conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Support, opposition, resistance and conformity (overall extent)
Sub_topics.description: Assess extent of support for Nazi regime and reasons for conformity; distinguish between opposition, resistance and non-conformity and why each occurred.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Church opposition: Pastor Niemöller
Sub_topics.description: Explain opposition from churches including role of Pastor Niemöller; link to Confessing Church and repression.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Youth opposition: Swing Youth and Edelweiss Pirates
Sub_topics.description: Explain opposition from young people including Swing Youth and Edelweiss Pirates; describe motivations, activities and Nazi responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nazi views on women and family
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nazi ideology about women and family (Kinder, Küche, Kirche; motherhood, racial duty) and how it shaped policy goals.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Policies towards women: marriage/family, employment and appearance
Sub_topics.description: Describe Nazi policies towards women: marriage/family incentives, employment restrictions/changes, and expectations about appearance; analyse effects and contradictions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nazi aims/policies for the young: Hitler Youth and League of German Maidens
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nazi aims for young people and how Hitler Youth and League of German Maidens indoctrinated and prepared youth; analyse methods and appeal/compulsion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Education control: curriculum and teachers
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nazi control of education including curriculum changes and control of teachers; link to ideology, obedience and militarism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Unemployment reduction policies: labour service, autobahns, rearmament, invisible unemployment
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nazi policies to reduce unemployment: labour service, autobahns, rearmament and ‘invisible unemployment’; analyse effectiveness and propaganda value.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Living standards and worker organisations: Labour Front, Strength Through Joy, Beauty of Labour
Sub_topics.description: Explain changes in living standards of workers; describe Labour Front and programmes Strength Through Joy and Beauty of Labour; analyse how they controlled labour and won support.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Racial beliefs and persecution of minorities (Slavs, Roma/Sinti, homosexuals, disabled)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nazi racial beliefs; describe treatment of minority groups including Slavs, Roma and Sinti, homosexuals, and people with disabilities; link to social Darwinism, eugenics and repression.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Persecution of Jewish people: boycott (1933), Nuremberg Laws, Kristallnacht
Sub_topics.description: Explain escalation of persecution of Jewish people: boycott of Jewish shops/businesses (1933), Nuremberg Laws, and Kristallnacht; analyse how policy moved from discrimination to violence and exclusion.

Topics.Strand: Paper 3: Modern depth study

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Civil War 1945–49: CCP vs Guomindang strengths/weaknesses
Sub_topics.description: Compare strengths and weaknesses of CCP and Guomindang at start of Civil War; link to control areas, corruption, popular support and military capacity.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why CCP won: leadership, military factors, urban unrest
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Mao/CCP success including leadership, military factors and unrest in towns/cities; analyse why Guomindang support collapsed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mao’s ideology and dominant role
Sub_topics.description: Explain Mao’s ideology and role; analyse reasons for his dominant position within CCP and China’s new state.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: CCP government: mass membership and democratic centralism
Sub_topics.description: Explain CCP role in governing China including new mass party membership and democratic centralism; describe how decision-making and control operated.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Terror against opponents (1951–52)
Sub_topics.description: Explain how terror was used to consolidate CCP power 1951–52; link to campaigns, executions and intimidation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Three-antis and five-antis campaigns
Sub_topics.description: Describe ‘three antis’ and ‘five antis’ movements; explain targets, methods and significance for control of bureaucracy/business and creating compliance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hundred Flowers campaign: Mao’s reasons
Sub_topics.description: Explain Mao’s reasons for launching Hundred Flowers campaign 1956–57; link to policy feedback, legitimacy and power struggle.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hundred Flowers: features, criticism and Mao’s reaction
Sub_topics.description: Describe key features: encouraging criticism; explain nature of criticism and Mao’s reaction; analyse why openness led to crackdown.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anti-Rightist purge and results of Hundred Flowers
Sub_topics.description: Explain results including Anti-Rightist purge; analyse effects on intellectuals, policy debate and Mao’s authority.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Landlordism attacks and land redistribution (1949–57)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and features of attacks on landlordism and redistribution of land; link to class struggle ideology and rural support.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Moves toward agricultural cooperation
Sub_topics.description: Describe moves toward agricultural cooperation and explain aims and outcomes before full collectivisation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: From voluntary to enforced collectivisation: reasons
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for shift from voluntary to enforced collectivisation; link to production targets, control and ideological goals.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First Five-Year Plan: reasons, targets, USSR support
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and targets of first Five-Year Plan; analyse significance of USSR financial and technical support for industrial development.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First Five-Year Plan: successes and failures
Sub_topics.description: Assess successes and failures of first Five-Year Plan in industry/agriculture balance, output and living standards.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Leap Forward: reasons and aims (1958–62)
Sub_topics.description: Explain Mao’s reasons for Great Leap Forward (second Five-Year Plan) 1958–62; link to desire for rapid industrialisation, independence from USSR and mass mobilisation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Leap Forward: successes/failures and reasons; Lushan Conference (1959)
Sub_topics.description: Assess successes and failures of Great Leap Forward; explain reasons for failures and importance of Lushan Conference (1959) for criticism and Mao’s response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Communes: organisation, communal living, abolition of private farming; Lysenkoism
Sub_topics.description: Describe organisation of communes including communal living and abolition of private farming; explain significance of Lysenkoism and how pseudo-science affected policy and yields.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Famine (1958–62): causes and impact
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes and impact of Great Famine 1958–62; link to policy errors, reporting, weather, procurement and human consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Restoration of private farming: reasons (Liu Shaoqi and Deng Xiaoping)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for restoration of private farming under Liu Shaoqi and Deng Xiaoping; link to recovery needs after famine and pragmatic policy shift.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Economic reform (1962–65): reasons and features under Liu and Deng
Sub_topics.description: Describe reasons for and features of economic reform 1962–65 under Liu and Deng; analyse how reforms altered incentives, production and Mao’s influence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cultural Revolution: power struggle (Mao vs Liu and Deng)
Sub_topics.description: Explain power struggle between Mao, Liu Shaoqi and Deng Xiaoping and how it contributed to launch of Cultural Revolution.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Purification of communism; Socialist Education Movement; education reform
Sub_topics.description: Explain aims of ‘purification’ including Socialist Education Movement and reform of education; link to ideology and Mao’s attempt to reassert control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mao and youth: 1966 mass rallies; Jiang Qing attacks on CCP
Sub_topics.description: Explain Mao’s hold on young people including 1966 mass rallies; describe Jiang Qing’s role and attack on CCP; link to mobilisation and factionalism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Red Guards: four olds, terror, anarchy and cultural destruction
Sub_topics.description: Describe Red Guard attacks on ‘four olds’ and CCP; explain growth of anarchy and use of terror; know examples of cultural destruction and why it occurred.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Political effects: purging CCP, Liu/Deng; rise/fall of Lin Biao
Sub_topics.description: Explain political effects of Cultural Revolution: purging of CCP; downfall of Liu Shaoqi and Deng Xiaoping; rise and fall of Lin Biao and significance for Mao’s regime.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Social effects: education impact
Sub_topics.description: Explain social effects including impact on education (school/university disruption, ‘sent-down youth’) and long-term consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Economic effects: industry disruption, technicians removed, countryside movement and farming impact
Sub_topics.description: Explain economic effects: changes in industry, removal of technicians, movement to countryside and impact on farming; analyse why production suffered.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: End of Red Guards and PLA restores order; Up to the mountains campaign
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for ending of Red Guards and significance of PLA restoring order; know ‘Up to the mountains and down to the villages’ campaign and its purpose/effects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Deng’s return, Zhou Enlai influence; Gang of Four; Mao’s death
Sub_topics.description: Explain return of Deng Xiaoping and increased influence of Zhou Enlai; describe rise and fall of Gang of Four and significance of Mao’s death for end of Cultural Revolution and future direction.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Propaganda/censorship and cult of Mao
Sub_topics.description: Explain communist control through propaganda and censorship; describe significance of cult of Mao and how it shaped loyalty and policy acceptance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thought control and Reform Through Labour system
Sub_topics.description: Explain thought control and development of ‘Reform Through Labour’ system; describe how it operated and its role in repression and re-education.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Family life changes in towns/countryside; impact of collectivisation/communes
Sub_topics.description: Explain changes in family life in towns and countryside; analyse impact of collectivisation and communes on relationships, work and living arrangements.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Women’s status: reasons for change; foot binding and Marriage Law (1950)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for changes in status of women under Mao; know significance of ending foot binding and Marriage Law (1950); analyse effects on equality, family and work.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Education reform and literacy growth
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for changes in education under Mao; describe growth in literacy and the significance of Pinyin.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Collapse of education after 1966
Sub_topics.description: Explain the collapse of education after 1966 and its consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Healthcare reform: reasons; barefoot doctors; successes and failures
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for changes in health provision; know significance of barefoot doctors; assess successes and failures of healthcare reform in Mao’s China.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Attacks on traditional culture; revolutionary art and Jiang Qing
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for attacks on traditional culture in towns/countryside; describe imposition of revolutionary art and culture and role of Jiang Qing.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Attacks on religions and beliefs (Buddhism, Confucianism, Christianity, Islam, ancestor worship)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for attacks on Buddhism, Confucianism, Christianity, Islam and ancestor worship; analyse how campaigns sought to reshape belief systems and social control.

Topics.Strand: Paper 3: Modern depth study
Topics.Topic_name: The USA, 1954–75: conflict at home and abroad

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Black Americans in early 1950s: segregation, discrimination and voting rights in South
Sub_topics.description: Describe position of Black Americans in early 1950s: segregation, discrimination and voting rights restrictions in Southern states; link to Jim Crow and everyday impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Civil rights organisations: NAACP and CORE
Sub_topics.description: Explain work of civil rights organisations including NAACP and CORE; describe strategies (legal challenge, direct action) and significance for early movement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Brown v. Topeka (1954): reasons, features and significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for, key features and significance of Brown v. Topeka (1954) decision; link to Supreme Court, school desegregation and resistance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Little Rock High School (1957): reasons, events and significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for, key features and significance of Little Rock High School events (1957); link to federal vs state power and media impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Montgomery Bus Boycott: causes/events; Rosa Parks significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes and events of Montgomery Bus Boycott; know significance of Rosa Parks and why her arrest sparked mass protest.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why boycott succeeded; Supreme Court ruling; Civil Rights Act (1957)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for success/importance of boycott; know Supreme Court ruling; explain Civil Rights Act (1957) and its limits/significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Martin Luther King and creation of SCLC
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Martin Luther King’s leadership and setting up of SCLC; link to non-violent strategy and mobilisation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: KKK violence and Emmet Till (1955)
Sub_topics.description: Explain opposition via KKK and violence; know murder of Emmet Till (1955) and its significance for national awareness and activism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Southern opposition: Dixiecrats and White Citizens’ Councils
Sub_topics.description: Explain opposition to desegregation including Dixiecrats and White Citizens’ Councils; describe methods (political resistance, intimidation) and impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Greensboro sit-ins significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Greensboro and sit-in movement; link to youth activism, direct action and spread of protest.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Freedom Riders: reasons, features, significance; Anniston bomb and KKK violence
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for, key features and significance of Freedom Riders; know KKK violence and Anniston bomb (1961); analyse federal response and media effect.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: James Meredith case (1962)
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of James Meredith case (1962); link to university desegregation, riots and federal enforcement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Birmingham and Washington marches (1963)
Sub_topics.description: Explain King and peace marches of 1963 in Birmingham and Washington; analyse aims, events (e.g., policing response) and impact on public opinion/policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Freedom Summer and Mississippi murders
Sub_topics.description: Explain Freedom Summer and Mississippi murders; analyse significance for voting rights campaign, national attention and dangers faced by activists.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Civil Rights Act (1964): roles of Kennedy and Johnson; impact of peaceful protest
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of peaceful protest and roles of Presidents Kennedy and Johnson in passage of Civil Rights Act (1964); link to legislative change and limits.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Selma and Voting Rights Act (1965)
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Selma campaign and Voting Rights Act (1965); analyse how events pressured government and changed political participation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Malcolm X: beliefs, methods, Black Muslims, later change and assassination
Sub_topics.description: Explain Malcolm X’s beliefs/methods and involvement with Black Muslims; describe later change of attitude and assassination; analyse significance for movement diversity and radicalism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Black Power emergence; Stokely Carmichael; Mexico Olympics (1968)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for emergence of Black Power; know significance of Stokely Carmichael and 1968 Mexico Olympics salute; link to pride, self-defence and media reaction.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Black Panthers: methods and achievements
Sub_topics.description: Explain methods and achievements of Black Panther movement (community programmes, self-defence, political messaging) and government/police response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Riots (1965–67) and Kerner Report (1968)
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes and nature of riots 1965–67; know Kerner Report (1968) findings and significance for understanding urban inequality and policy debates.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: King’s Northern campaign; assassination and impact
Sub_topics.description: Explain King’s campaign in the North; describe assassination and impact; analyse effect on movement, public opinion and unrest.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Extent of progress in civil rights by 1975
Sub_topics.description: Assess extent of progress in civil rights by 1975; consider legal gains vs continuing inequality in housing, jobs, policing and education.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Eisenhower involvement: domino theory and Diem weaknesses
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for greater US involvement under Eisenhower including domino theory and weaknesses of Diem government; link to Cold War containment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kennedy involvement: Diem overthrow and Strategic Hamlet Program
Sub_topics.description: Explain greater involvement under Kennedy including Strategic Hamlet Program and overthrow of Diem; analyse how policies escalated instability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Johnson escalation: Vietcong threat and Gulf of Tonkin (1964)
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for escalation under Johnson including Vietcong threat and Gulf of Tonkin incident (1964); link to congressional support and troop increases.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Vietcong guerrilla tactics
Sub_topics.description: Describe guerrilla tactics used by Vietcong and explain why they were effective against US forces.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: US tactics: Search and Destroy, Rolling Thunder, chemical weapons
Sub_topics.description: Explain US methods including Search and Destroy, Operation Rolling Thunder and chemical weapons; analyse effectiveness and impact on civilians/support.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Tet Offensive (1968): features and significance
Sub_topics.description: Describe key features of Tet Offensive (1968) and explain its significance for military perception, US public opinion and policy shift.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Vietnamisation: features and reasons for failure
Sub_topics.description: Explain Vietnamisation under Nixon: key features and reasons for its failure; link to ARVN capability, continued North Vietnamese strength and US politics.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nixon Doctrine and troop withdrawal
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nixon Doctrine and how it related to withdrawal of US troops; link to burden-sharing and Cold War strategy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cambodia (1970), Laos (1971) and bombing of North Vietnam (1972)
Sub_topics.description: Describe US attacks on Cambodia and Laos and bombing of North Vietnam; explain aims and consequences for war and domestic opposition.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Why opposition grew: students, TV/media, draft
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for growth of opposition to the war: student movement, TV/media coverage and the draft system; analyse how these changed public attitudes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: My Lai Massacre (1968) and Calley trial: public reaction
Sub_topics.description: Explain public reaction to My Lai Massacre and significance of Lt. Calley’s trial; link to morality, trust in government and media exposure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kent State shootings (1970)
Sub_topics.description: Describe Kent State University shootings (1970) and explain significance for anti-war movement and political division.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reasons for support: fear of communism
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons some Americans supported the war, including fear of communism; link to Cold War ideology and patriotism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hard hats and silent majority
Sub_topics.description: Explain who the ‘hard hats’ and ‘silent majority’ were and why they supported the war; analyse significance for US politics and social conflict.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Peace negotiations (1972–73): reasons and features
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and key features of peace negotiations (1972–73); link to military stalemate, domestic pressure and diplomacy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Paris Peace Agreement (1973) significance
Sub_topics.description: Explain significance of Paris Peace Agreement (1973) and how it ended direct US involvement; link to political consequences at home and in Vietnam.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Costs of war for USA: economic and human
Sub_topics.description: Explain economic and human costs of the war for the USA; link to budget strain, casualties, veterans and social impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: North Vietnamese strengths: USSR/China support, Vietcong tactics, Ho Chi Minh Trail
Sub_topics.description: Explain strengths of North Vietnam including support from USSR/China, Vietcong tactics and Ho Chi Minh Trail; analyse how these offset US firepower.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: US weaknesses: armed forces issues and tactic failures
Sub_topics.description: Explain weaknesses of US armed forces and failure of US tactics; link to morale, unfamiliar terrain, guerrilla warfare and strategic limits.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of US domestic opposition on failure in Vietnam
Sub_topics.description: Analyse how opposition to the war in the USA affected government strategy, troop levels and willingness to continue; explain contribution to ultimate failure.
